This play was produced on Monday , August 9 ,1920, at the Aldwych Theatre with the following cast : COLONEL WHARTON MR. CHARLES V.FRANCEMAJOR WHARTON ( JOHN ) MR . BASIL RATHBONE MRS. WHARTON LADY TREE MRS. LITTLEWOOD MISS HAIDEE WRIGHT REV . NORMAN POOLE MR. H. R. HIGNETT MRS. POOLE MISS LENA HALLIDAY SYLVIA BULLOUGH MISS ELLEN O ’ MALLEY DR. MACFARLANE MR. CLARENCE BLAKISTON KATE MISS GWENDOLEN FFLOYD

set.p: The action of the play takes place at the Manor House , Stour , in the County of Kent .

titlePage.docImprint: The author ventures to suggest to the readers of this play that he makes no pretensions to throw a new light on any of the questions which are discussed in it , nor has he attempted to offer a solution of problems which , judging from the diversity of opinion which they have occasioned , may be regarded as insoluble . He has tried to put into dramatic form some of the thoughts and emotions which have recently agitated many , and for this purpose he has chosen the most ordinary characters in the circle with which , owing to his own circumstances , he is best acquainted . But because it is a good many years since he was on terms of intimate familiarity with a parish priest , and he was not certain how much the views of the clergy had changed , the author has put into the mouth of the Rev . Norman Poole phrases from Dr. Gore ’ s “ The Religion of the Church ,” and from a sermon by Dr. Stewart Holden . Since it is impossible in a play to indicate by quotation marks what is borrowed , the author takes this opportunity to acknowledge his indebtedness for the Rev . Norman Poole ’ s most characteristic speeches .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: The drawing-room at the Manor House , COLONEL WHARTON ’ S residence . It is a simple room , somewhat heavily furnished in an old-fashioned style ; there is nothing in it which is in the least artistic ; but the furniture is comfortable , and neither new nor shabby . On the papered walls are the Academy pictures of forty years ago . There are a great many framed photographs of men in uniform , and here and there a bunch of simple flowers in a vase . The only things in the room which are at all exotic are silver ornaments from Indian bazaars and flimsy Indian fabrics , used as cloths on the occasional tables and as drapery on the piano .
At the back are French windows leading into the garden ; and this , with its lawn and trees , is seen through them . It is summer , and the windows are open . Morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON is sitting in the corner of the sofa , knitting a
sp.p: khaki comforter . She is a slight , tall woman of five-and-fifty ; she has deliberate features , with kind eyes and a gentle look ; her dark hair is getting very gray ; it is simply done ; and her dress , too , is simple ; it is not at all new and was never fashionable . KATE , a middle-aged maid-servant , in a print dress , a cap and apron , comes in .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: If you please , ma ’ am , the butcher ’ s called .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh ! I arranged with Cook that we should have cold roast beef again for luncheon to-day , Kate . Tell the butcher to bring two and a half pounds of the best end of the neck for to-night , and tell him to pick me out a really nice piece , Kate . It ’ s so long since the Major has had any good English meat .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: And he might send in a couple of kidneys . The Colonel and Major Wharton enjoyed the kidneys that they had for breakfast yesterday so much .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , ma ’ am . If you please , ma ’ am , the gardener hasn ’ t sent in a very big basket of pease . Cook says it won ’ t look much for three .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , well , it doesn ’ t matter as long as there are enough for the gentlemen . I ’ ll just pretend to take some .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very good , ma ’ am . As she is going , COLONEL WHARTON enters from the garden with a basket of cherries . He is a thin old man , much older than his wife , with white hair ; but though very frail he still carries himself erectly . His face is bronzed by long exposure to tropical suns , but even so it is the face of a sick man . He wears a light tweed suit which hangs about him loosely , as though he had shrunk since it was made for him . He has a round tweed hat of the same material .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Has the paper come yet , Kate ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Yes , sir . I ’ ll bring it .

div.stage: Exit KATE

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ ve brought you in some cherries , Evelyn . They ’ re the only ripe ones I could find .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , that is nice . I hope you ’ re not tired .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Great Scott , I ’ m not such a crock that it can tire me to pick a few cherries . If I ’ d been able to find a ladder I ’ d have got you double the number .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , my dear , you ’ d better let the gardener get them . I don ’ t approve of your skipping up and down ladders .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: The gardener ’ s just as old as I am and not nearly so active . Hasn ’ t John come in yet ? He said he was only going to the post .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Perhaps he went in to see Sylvia on the way back .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have thought she wanted to be bothered with him in the morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: George !

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Yes , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It seems so extraordinary to hear you say : “ Hasn ’ t John come in yet ? He said he was only going to the post .” It makes me rather want to cry .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s been a long time , Evelyn . It ’ s been a bad time for both of us , my dear . But worse for you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I tried not to be troublesome , George .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Dear child , aren ’ t I there to share your troubles with you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It seems so natural that he should come in any minute , it seems as though he ’ d never been away — and yet somehow I can ’ t quite believe it . It seems incredible that he should really be back .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Patting her hand .My dear Evelyn !

div.stage: KATE brings in the paper and gives it to the COLONEL . She goes out .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Thank you .While he puts on his spectacles .It ’ s a blessing to be able to read the births , deaths , and marriages like a gentleman instead of turning before anything else to the casualties .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I hope before long that we shall be composing a little announcement for that column .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Have they settled a day yet , those young people ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t know . John hasn ’ t said anything , and I didn ’ t see Sylvia yesterday except for a moment after church .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Evelyn dear , the gardener tells me he hasn ’ t got much in the way of pease ready for to-night , so I ’ ve told him to send in a few carrots for me ; I think they ’ re probably better for my digestion .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Nonsense , George . You know how much you like pease , and I ’ m not very fond of them . I was hoping there ’ d only be enough for two so that I shouldn ’ t have to eat any .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Evelyn , where do you expect to go when you die if you tell such stories ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Now , George , don ’ t be obstinate . You might give in to me sometimes . They ’ re the first pease out of the garden and I should like you to eat them .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: No , my dear , I ’ d like to see you eat them . I ’ m an invalid , and I must have my own way .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You tyrant ! You haven ’ t seen Dr. Macfarlane this morning ? I ’ m so anxious .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You old fusser ! No sooner have you stopped worrying over your boy than you start worrying over me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Even though you won ’ t let me call my soul my own , I don ’ t want to lose you just yet .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Don ’ t be alarmed . I shall live to plague you for another twenty years .

div.stage: KATE comes in .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: If you please , ma ’ am , Mrs. Poole has called .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Why haven ’ t you shown her in ?

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: She wouldn ’ t come in , ma ’ am . She said she was passing and she just stopped to enquire how you were .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Tell her to come in , Kate . What ’ s she making all this fuss about .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I expect she wants to hear all about John .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: If she ’ ll wait a minute she ’ ll have the chance of seeing the young fellow himself .

div.stage: KATE comes in , followed by MRS. POOLE . The visitor is a thin , rather dour person of middle age , brisk in her movements , competent and firm . She is a woman who knows her own mind and has no hesitation in speaking it . She is not unsympathetic . She wears a serviceable black coat and skirt and a black straw hat .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mrs. Poole .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: What do you mean by trying to get away without showing yourself ? Is this how you do your district visiting ?

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Shaking hands with MRS. WHARTON and with the COLONEL .I wanted to come in , but I thought you mightn ’ t wish to see me to-day , so I put it like that to make it easier for you to send me about my business .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: We always wish to see you , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: If I had a son that I hadn ’ t seen for four years and he ’ d been dangerously wounded , I think I ’ d want to keep him to myself for the first few days after he got home .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Then you ’ re not as unselfish a woman as Evelyn .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Or perhaps not nearly so vain .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Did you go down to the station to meet him on Saturday ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: The Colonel went . He wouldn ’ t let me go because he said I ’ d make a fool of myself on the platform .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I took Sylvia . I thought that was enough . I knew I could trust her to control herself .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: And when are they going to be married .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , I hope very soon . It ’ s been a long and anxious time for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Can you bear to give him up when he ’ s only just come back to you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , but it ’ s not giving him up when he ’ s marrying Sylvia . She ’ s been like a daughter to us . D ’ you know , they ’ ve been engaged for seven years .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I hope they ’ ll be very happy . Sylvia certainly deserves to be .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: She ’ s done cheerfully the most difficult thing anyone can do . All through the war when she was pining to be off and do her bit she stayed at home with a bed-ridden mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Bullough .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Yes , but poor Sylvia too . It ’ s easy enough to do your duty when duty is dangerous and exciting , but when you can do nothing — no one knows better than I what it is to sit still and look on when others are doing the things that are worth while . This war came ten years too late for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: That ’ s what the Vicar has been saying ever since the war began . But after all your son has taken your place , and I think you can be proud of him .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: With intense satisfaction .The rascal with his Military Cross and his D. S. O .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I ’ m so glad that his first day here was a Sunday .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You don ’ t know what I felt when we knelt down side by side in church . I was very grateful .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I know . I could see it in your face and the Colonel ’ s .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: God has vouchsafed us a great mercy .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: The Vicar was dreadfully disappointed that he didn ’ t stay for Holy Communion . You know that he looks upon that as the essential part of the service .

lg.l: I think we were a little disappointed , too . We were so surprised when
John walked out .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Did he say why he had ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No . I talked it over with the Colonel . We didn ’ t quite know what to do . I don ’ t know whether to mention it or not .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I do hope he ’ ll stay next Sunday .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He was always a very regular communicant .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t see why you shouldn ’ t say something to him about it , Evelyn .

lg.l: I will if you like .
lg.stage: There is the sound of a laugh in the garden .
lg.l: Why , here he is . And Sylvia .

div.stage: SYLVIA BULLOUGH and JOHN WHARTON come in . She is no longer quite young . She has a pleasant , friendly look rather than beauty , and she suggests the homely virtues of a girl very well brought up in a nice English family ; she gives the impression of a practical , competent , and sensible woman . She will make a good wife and an excellent mother . She is very simply dressed in light summery things , and she wears a straw hat . She is carrying a string bag , in which are a number of household purchases . JOHN WHARTON is in mufti . He is a man of thirty .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Good morning everybody !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , how nice of you to come in .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: She didn ’ t want to , but I made her .

div.stage: SYLVIA kisses MRS. WHARTON and shakes hands with MRS. POOLE , then she kisses the COLONEL .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Gaily .That ’ s a deliberate lie , John .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: This is my son , Mrs. Poole .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .I daresay you suspected it .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I had a good look at you in church , you know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Is that how vicars ’ wives behave themselves ?

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: They allow themselves a little licence when young people come home on leave .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Did you meet in the village ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not exactly . I saw Sylvia darting into Mrs. Gann ’ s shop , evidently to avoid me ....

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Interrupting .I don ’ t know how you imagined I could see you out of the back of my head .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: So I ran like a hare , and caught her in the very act of buying two pounds of vermicelli .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: To say nothing of a tin of sardines and a packet of mustard .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now take off your hat , Sylvia . You mustn ’ t hide the best feature you ’ ve got .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Taking it off .I hope you don ’ t think I shall go on doing exactly what you tell me a minute after the war ’ s over .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I haven ’ t noticed any startling alacrity to do what I tell you as it is .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You ungrateful fellow ! When have I hesitated to carry out your slightest wish ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He ’ s only been back forty-eight hours , poor dear .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Didn ’ t I go down to you on my bended knees in the middle of the road and ask you to come for a walk with me ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , well , I wanted to see your father . I was anxious to hear what the specialist had said .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Surprised .Have you been seeing a specialist , father ? Aren ’ t you well ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Perfectly . It was only to satisfy your poor mother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But why didn ’ t you tell me ? Is anything the matter with him , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , your father wouldn ’ t let me tell you anything about it when you came . He didn ’ t want you to be worried . And I thought myself it might just as well keep till to-day .

lg.l: The fact is I haven ’ t been quite up to the mark lately , and Dr .
Macfarlane thought I ’ d better see a specialist . So I went into
Canterbury on Saturday and saw Dr. Keller .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Yes , I heard you ’ d been to see him . They say he ’ s very clever .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What did he say ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Well , you know what these doctor fellows are . He wouldn ’ t say much to me . He said he ’ d write to Macfarlane .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I suppose Macfarlane got the letter this morning . He ’ ll probably be round presently .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I saw him going along the Bleane Road in his dog-cart about an hour ago . You might ask him who it was he was going to see .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you feeling ill , father ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: No . I shouldn ’ t have dreamed of going to a specialist , only your mother was worrying .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Don ’ t put all the blame on her . I was , too .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Going over to him and putting his arm in his .Poor old father , you mustn ’ t be ill .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m not going to die just yet , you know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should jolly well think not . Wait till you ’ re a hundred and two , and then we ’ ll begin talking about it .

div.stage: The Vicar of Stour , the REV . NORMAN POOLE , appears at the window . He is a tall , thin man , bald , dressed in a short black coat , with a black straw hat . He is energetic , breezy , and cheerful . He likes to show that , although a clergyman , he is a man ; and he affects a rather professional joviality . MR. and MRS. POOLE have that physical resemblance which you sometimes see in married people . You wonder if they married because they were so much alike , or if it is marriage which has created the similarity .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Hulloa , hulloa , hulloa ! May I come in ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Smiling .Of course . How do you do ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: My dear Vicar !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Entering .I suppose I ought to have gone round to the front door , and rung the bell like a gentleman . My dear Dorothy , when will you teach me how to behave ?

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I ’ ve long given up the attempt .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I thought I ’ d look in and say how-do-you-do to the wounded hero .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My son . The Vicar .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Welcome ! I passed you in the village just now . I had half a mind to come up and wring your hand , but I thought you ’ d say , who the deuce is this clerical gent ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: An authentic hero . And he speaks just like you and me . The world ’ s a strange place , my masters . Well , what d ’ you think of Blighty ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m very glad to be home again . I thought I never should get back .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You ’ ve not been home since the beginning of the war , have you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , you see I was in India when it broke out . What with Gallipoli and one thing and another , I was done out of my leave every time .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Well , it ’ s a long lane that has no turning . But I understand that you ’ ve picked up some bits and pieces here and there . The Military Cross and the D. S. O ., isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: You must be a very proud man .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: How did you win them ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t know . Playing about generally .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t think you ’ ll get very much more than that out of John .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: To JOHN .You lucky beggar ! You ’ ve had your chance and you were able to take it . That ’ s where I should have been , where my heart was , with the brave lads at the front . And my confounded chest has kept me chained to this little tin-pot parish .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: My husband suffers from his lungs .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m sorry to hear that .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Yes , the Great White Peril . They say its ravages are terrible . That ’ s why I came here , you know ; I was in charge of the parish of St. Jude ’ s , Stoke Newington when I crocked up . I tried to get them to let me go when the war broke out , but they wouldn ’ t hear of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: They also serve who only stand and wait .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I know , I know . It ’ s this confounded energy of mine . I ’ m a crock , and I ’ ve just had to make the best of it . I ’ m on the shelf . The future is in the hands of you brave lads who ’ ve been through the fire . I suppose you went to sleep during my sermon yesterday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not at all . I listened to it very attentively .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t blame you if you had . That ’ s about all I ’ ve been able to do during the war , to preach . And , upon my word , I sometimes wonder what good I ’ ve done .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You ’ ve been a great help to us all .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: For my part I don ’ t deplore the war . Our Lord said : “ Think not that I come to send peace on earth : I came not to send peace , but a sword .” The Christian Church has lived by her sword . Every advance which this world of ours has known in liberty , in justice , in enlightenment , has been won for it by the sword of Jesus Christ .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I wish all parsons were as broad-minded . I know what war is . I was in Egypt and in South Africa . I ’ ve been through half a dozen wars in India . I have no use for slop and sentimentality . My own belief is that war is necessary to a nation . It brings out all a man ’ s best qualities .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: There I heartily agree with you . It is the great school of character . Amid the clash of arms the great Christian virtues shine forth with an immortal lustre . Courage , self-sacrifice , charity , self-reliance . No one knew before the war what a pinnacle of heroism was within the power of our brave lads at the front .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: What do you think about it , Major Wharton ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Smiling .I ? I think it ’ s a lovely day . I have three weeks leave , and the war is a long way off .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: With a chuckle .A very good answer . I ’ ve been saying the obvious , I know that just as well as you do , but , you know , sometimes the obvious has to be said , and when it has , I think a man should have the courage to say it . Now , my dear , let ’ s be off .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I don ’ t know what Mrs. Wharton will think of us for inflicting ourselves on her like this .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We ’ re all friends here , I hope and trust . If we weren ’ t welcome , Mrs. Wharton only had to say so . To my mind the afternoon call is a convention more honoured in the breach than the observance .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s been very good of you to come .

div.stage: There is a general shaking of hands .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: To JOHN .Well , good-bye , young fellow . I ’ ve tried to show you that I ’ m by way of being rather broad-minded as parsons go . It wouldn ’ t shock me in the least to hear you say “ damn ” or “ blast .” I ’ m often inclined to use a bit of strong language myself . I asked you just now if you ’ d gone to sleep during my sermon . I wouldn ’ t have turned a hair if you had .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you to say so . I may avail myself of your suggestion on some future occasion .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: On a future occasion , perhaps — shall we say next Sunday ?— I hope you won ’ t leave the House of God without partaking in the greatest of all the Sacraments of our Church . Don ’ t forget that the Almighty has in His mercy brought you in safety through great and terrible peril . That ’ s all I wanted to say to you . Good-bye , God bless you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Shaking hands with MRS. WHARTONGood-bye . These parsons , what a nuisance they make of themselves , don ’ t they ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I wanted to ask you if you ’ d seen poor Mrs. Littlewood since her return .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No , she didn ’ t come to church yesterday . And of course , Sunday ’ s my busy day — I ’ m the only man in the parish who works seven days a week — so I haven ’ t had a chance to see her yet , poor soul .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: She came down by the 6. 35 on Saturday . She was in the same train as John , but I wasn ’ t bothering much about anyone else just then , and I didn ’ t speak to her .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I wish we could do something for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Explaining to JOHN .She was telegraphed for last week to go to Ned at Boulogne . He died on Tuesday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With astonishment .Ned ! But he was only a kid .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , he ’ d grown up since you were home . He was nearly nineteen .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Both her sons are gone now . She ’ s quite alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: We must all be very kind to her . It will be terrible for her in that big house all by herself . I wish you ’ d spoken to her on Saturday , George .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I felt rather shy about it . After all , we ’ ve had rather an anxious time over that young scamp there . If anything had happened to him — well , I should have had Evelyn , but she , poor soul , has nobody .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ought to have gone to see her yesterday .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: She must be absolutely prostrated with grief .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I wonder if she ’ d like to come and stay at the Vicarage . I can ’ t bear to think of her all alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: That ’ s a splendid idea , Norman , and just like you . I ’ ll ask her at once . I ’ ll be glad to do what I can for her .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Of course one ought to try and find something to occupy her mind .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Happily she has always been a deeply religious woman . When all ’ s said and done , in grief like that there ’ s only one unfailing refuge .

div.stage: KATE enters , followed by MRS. LITTLEWOOD . She is a little elderly woman . She is not dressed in mourning , but in the clothes she may be expected to have been wearing before her bereavement .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mrs. Littlewood .

div.stage: Exit KATE .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Rising and going to meet her .My dear friend , how very glad I am to see you .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: How do you do ?She smiles brightly at the assembled company .Oh , John , have you come back ?To MRS. WHARTON .I came to ask if you and the Colonel would come and play bridge this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Bridge !

div.stage: They all look at her with surprise , but no one says anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I was going to ask Dr. Macfarlane to make a fourth , but perhaps John will come .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With embarrassment .It ’ s very kind of you , but the Colonel hasn ’ t been very well lately . I don ’ t think he feels like going out , and I shouldn ’ t like to leave him .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m sorry .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Won ’ t you sit down ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Thank you very much . I won ’ t stay . I ’ ll go round to the Wilkinsons and see if they ’ ll play .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I hope you weren ’ t very tired by your journey .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I wasn ’ t tired at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: We thought you were , because we didn ’ t see you in church .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: No , I didn ’ t come . I thought it would bore me .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s silence .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Did you — did you come straight through from France ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: No . I stayed a couple of nights in London .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With pity in her voice .All alone ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: No . I picked up a very nice woman in the hotel , and we went out together . We went to the Gaiety one night and the next we went to the Empire . Do you know that I ’ d never seen George Robey before ?

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Who is George Robey ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I believe he ’ s a comedian .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Very pleasantly .How long are you here for , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I have three weeks ’ leave .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: We must all make much of you . I ’ ll give a tennis party for you , shall I ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Littlewood , I ’ m sure you don ’ t want to give parties just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I ’ d love to . It ’ s so seldom one gets an excuse for one in a place like this .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Taking her hand .My dear , I want you to know how deeply we all sympathise with you in your great loss .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Patting MRS. WHARTON ’ S hand , and then releasing her own .That ’ s very kind of you .To SYLVIA and JOHN .Would Wednesday suit you young people ? I ’ ll have both courts marked out .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Desperately .I couldn ’ t come , Mrs. Littlewood , I couldn ’ t come .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Why on earth not ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Controlling herself to civility .I ’ m engaged that day .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: John has so short a time at home . I think he and Sylvia have a feeling that they don ’ t want to go to parties .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Deliberately .I hope you got over to France in time to find your son alive .

div.stage: MRS. LITTLEWOOD gives him a rapid glance , stops a moment as though to collect herself , then answers almost indifferently .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: No , he was dead , poor child .To MRS. WHARTON .Good-bye , my dear , I ’ m sorry you can ’ t come and play bridge this afternoon . I suppose I shall have to send you a wedding-present , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I suppose you will .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: With a smile at the rest of the company .Good-bye .

div.stage: She goes out . They are left in amazement .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Is she absolutely heartless ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I always thought she was devoted to her sons .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: And Ned was her favourite .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: She wasn ’ t wearing mourning .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Isn ’ t she going to , do you suppose ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I can ’ t understand it . She adored those boys .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I didn ’ t ask her to come and stay at the Vicarage , Norman .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I don ’ t think we ’ d better till the situation ’ s a little clearer . She gives one the impression of not caring two straws for Ned ’ s death . She must be as hard as nails .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No , she isn ’ t that . I ’ ve known her for thirty-five years . D ’ you think she ’ s mad ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: We ’ d better say a word to Macfarlane when he comes , Evelyn .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I was never so taken aback in my life as when she said she didn ’ t come to church because she thought she ’ d be bored .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Norman , I must go . I ’ ve got a lot of things to do at home .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Come along then . We ’ ll just walk out through the garden .

div.stage: There are farewells , rather distracted by the queer incident that has just occurred , and the VICAR and MRS. POOLE go out . The COLONEL accompanies them to the door .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You ’ re very silent , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I was thinking about Mrs. Littlewood . She doesn ’ t give me the impression of being either callous or mad .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What does she mean , then ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Reflectively .I don ’ t know .With a shrug of the shoulders , throwing off his mood .And at the moment I don ’ t very much care . Come and sit down and be a comfort to a wounded hero .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Idiot !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Will you stay to luncheon , Sylvia dear ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , I think I ought to get back to mother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Before you go let ’ s tell them what we ’ ve been talking about .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t think it ’ s very hard to guess .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I want Sylvia to marry me as soon as ever it ’ s possible .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If we look nippy we can get a special licence and be married on Thursday . We don ’ t want to go far for our honeymoon , because I have such a short time . And my suggestion is London .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What do you think , Mrs. Wharton ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Well , my dear , I think that whatever you and John decide will be quite right .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: He ’ s only just come back to you . I can ’ t bear to take him away immediately . Wouldn ’ t you prefer us to wait a little longer ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , we ’ ve always decided that you should be married the moment he came back . We ’ ve been quite prepared to lose him . And perhaps after a few days , if the Colonel ’ s well enough , you wouldn ’ t mind if we came up to London , too . We ’ d try not to be in your way .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Going down on her knees beside MRS. WHARTON and kissing her .Oh , my dear , you ’ re so kind to me . I don ’ t know how I can ever thank you for all your kindness .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s been a weary , anxious time for all of us . I know how unhappy you ’ ve been sometimes . I want you to have him now . He ’ s a good boy , and I think he ’ ll make you happy .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Getting up and giving JOHN her hand .I ’ m sure he will . I ’ ll try to make you a good wife , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I expect you ’ ll be quite good enough for the likes of me . Then it ’ s to be Thursday next .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: With a smile .It is .

div.stage: He draws her to him and kisses her . She very nearly breaks down .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ ve wanted you for so long , John , so dreadfully long .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake don ’ t cry .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Breaking away from him , with a chuckle .You brute , John ! I hate you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Did you like the Vicar , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He seemed all right .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: He ’ s a first-rate fellow . He had a very good living in London at one time , and he resigned and took one in the East End instead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: He said he wasn ’ t ordained to drink China tea with elderly women of means .With a chuckle .He says very good things sometimes .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: They were perfectly wonderful in the East End . They wanted to live in exactly the same way as their parishioners , so they did without a servant , and did all their housework , even their washing , themselves .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It sounds hateful , but of course it really was heroic .

lg.l: D ’ you remember what he said to you about Holy Communion ? Your father and
I were a little disappointed that you didn ’ t stay for it yesterday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m sorry for that , mother dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It would have been such a great pleasure to both of us if we could all three have received it together .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Dear mother .... If you ’ re really going home to luncheon , Sylvia , I ’ ll walk back with you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: The Vicar has a Communion service on Wednesday morning . Would you come then ? It ’ ll be the last opportunity before your marriage .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , my dear , you ’ re not going to ask me to get up in the middle of the night ? After all , one of the pleasures of coming home is to lie in bed in the morning . I don ’ t know how I ever tear myself out of those lavender-scented sheets .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Dear John , won ’ t you come to please us ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Still trying to pass it off lightly .Oh , my dear mother , d ’ you think it ’ s really necessary ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I should like it so much , my dear . You know , it means a great deal to us .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: More gravely .Don ’ t you think one should go to a ceremony like that in a certain frame of mind ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Come , my boy , you ’ re not going to refuse the first request your mother has made you since you came back ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m awfully sorry , mother . I beg you not to insist .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t quite know what you mean . It ’ s not like you to be obstinate .... Won ’ t you come , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , mother .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ ve been away a long time . There are some things one can ’ t help , you know . I ’ ve been through very terrible experiences .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Aghast .Do you mean to say you ’ ve lost your — faith ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m awfully sorry to give you pain , dear .

lg.l: You ’ ve not answered your mother ’ s question ,
John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If you want a direct answer , I ’ m afraid it must be — yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Overcome .Oh , John !

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But you came to church yesterday .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That was just a formal ceremony . I assisted passively , as a Jew might assist at the wedding of one of his Christian friends .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You stood when we stood , and knelt down , and seemed to pray .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I would do that if I were in a Roman Catholic church . That seemed to me only good manners .With a smile .Do you think it was very deceitful ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I don ’ t quite see why you should strain at a gnat .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t . It ’ s the camel I can ’ t swallow . I knew it would distress you if I refused to come to church . I didn ’ t want to seem a prig . But the other seems to me different . When I ’ m asked to take an active part in a ceremony that means nothing to me it ’ s quite another matter . I ’ d rather not tell a deliberate lie . And surely from your point of view it would be blasphemous .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Occupied with her own thoughts .How dreadful !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Going up to her and putting his arm round her .Don ’ t be unhappy , mother . I can ’ t help feeling as I do . After all , these are matters that only concern oneself .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Reflecting .Are they ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Surely .To his mother .I would rather not have told you . I knew how much you ’ d take it to heart . But I was obliged to . And perhaps it ’ s better as it is . I hated the thought of deceiving you and father . Now let ’ s put it out of our minds .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: John , have you forgotten , that in three weeks you ’ ll be going back to the Front ? Sooner or later you ’ ll find yourself once more in the fighting line . Have you asked yourself what it will be like to face death without the help of Almighty God ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It ’ s always difficult to face death .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t be the first who found it easy to stand alone when all was going well and found it a very different thing in danger or illness .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .When the devil was sick , the devil a monk would be .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Archie , Mrs. Littlewood ’ s elder boy , was badly wounded on the Somme . His battalion had to retreat and somehow or other he wasn ’ t picked up . He lay in the corner of a wood for three days and kept himself alive on a beet that he pulled out of the field . Heaven knows , I don ’ t want anything like that to happen to you , but are you sure your courage wouldn ’ t fail you then ? Are you sure you wouldn ’ t call on God instinctively to help you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And if I did , what of it ? That wouldn ’ t be me , that mangled , bleeding , starved , delirious thing . It ’ s me now that speaks , now that I ’ m well and conscious and strong . It ’ s the real me now . I disclaim and disown anything I may feel or say when I ’ m tortured with pain and sickness . It would give my real self just as little as a prisoner on the rack gives the truth .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Looking at him fixedly .You ’ re afraid of something like that happening , aren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , I shouldn ’ t like my body to play me a dirty trick when I hadn ’ t the presence of mind to look after it .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Have you ever been in real danger since you — since you began to think like this ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes . Once I was in a trench the Germans had enfiladed . They ’ d got the line exactly . The shells fell one after another , first at the end of the trench , and then they came slowly down . One could calculate almost mathematically when the shell must come that would blow one to smithereens .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With a little gasp of terror .Oh , John , don ’ t !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Smiling .Well , something went wrong , or else I certainly shouldn ’ t be here now .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Do you mean to say you weren ’ t frightened ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Frightened isn ’ t the word for it . Talk of getting the wind up : it was a perfect hurricane . I felt as though I were shrinking up so that my clothes suddenly hung about me like sacks . And against my will a prayer came to my lips . From long habit , I suppose , they tried to form themselves into an appeal to God to turn the shell away . I had to fight with myself . I had to keep saying to myself : “ Don ’ t be a fool . Don ’ t be a damned fool .”

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: And you resisted ? It was the voice of God speaking to you . The prayer was said in your heart , and He in His mercy heard it . Doesn ’ t that prove to you that you ’ re wrong ? At that moment you believed , even though you struggled not to . Your whole soul cried out its belief in God .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , not my soul : my fear of death .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ ve been in battle , too . In South Africa and in the Soudan we were in some pretty tight places now and then . When I went into action I commended my soul to God , and now that I ’ m an old man I can say that I never knew fear .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t think I ’ m particularly brave . Before an attack I ’ ve often had to light a cigarette to hide the trembling of my lips .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: The Christian doesn ’ t fear death . His whole life is but a preparation for that awful moment . To him it is the shining gateway to life everlasting .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should be sorry to think that life was nothing but a preparation for death . To my mind death is very unimportant . I think a man does best to put it out of his thoughts . He should live as though life were endless . Life is the thing that matters .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Doesn ’ t that suggest a very base materialism ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , because you can ’ t make the most of life unless you ’ re willing to risk it , and it ’ s the risk that makes the difference . It ’ s the most precious thing a man has , but it ’ s valueless unless he ’ s prepared to stake it .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What do you think it can be worth while to risk life for ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Almost anything . Honour or love . A song , a thought .After a moment ’ s reflection , with a smile .A five-barred gate .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Isn ’ t that rather illogical ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Perhaps . I don ’ t put it very well . I think what I mean is that life in itself has no value . It ’ s what you put in it that gives it worth .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Why do you think you ’ ve come safely through the perils and dangers of the war ? John , do you know that every day your mother and Sylvia and I prayed that God might see fit to spare you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With sudden energy .Were you the only ones ? Why didn ’ t He see fit to spare the others ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Who are we to question the inscrutable designs of the Omnipotent ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Answering his son .I don ’ t know what you mean by that . In war somebody ’ s got to be killed . When a commander gives battle he knows pretty accurately what his losses are going to be before he starts .

div.stage: JOHN gives a slight shrug of the shoulders . He recovers his equanimity .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If you don ’ t mind my saying so , I think we ’ d much better not start arguing . Arguments never bring one much forrader , do they ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Gently .But we want to understand , John . You were always such a pious boy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Smiling .Oh , mother , that ’ s rather a terrible thing to say to anybody .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With an answering smile .Oh , I didn ’ t mean it like that . On the contrary , you were rather troublesome . Sometimes you were very headstrong and obstinate .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That ’ s better .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: We tried to bring you up to fear God . It used to make me happy sometimes to see how simple and touching your faith was . You used to pray to God for all sorts of absurd things , to make a lot of runs in a cricket match or to pass an exam , that you hadn ’ t worked for .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , I remember .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: If you ’ ve lost your faith , we know it can ’ t be as so many lose it , on purpose , because they ’ ve given themselves over to sensuality , and dare not believe in a God whom every action of their lives insults . If you ’ ll only tell us everything , perhaps we can help you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear , you ’ d much better let the matter rest . I should only have to say things that would hurt you all .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: We ’ re willing to take the risk of that . We know you wouldn ’ t hurt us intentionally . Perhaps they ’ re only difficulties that we might be able to explain . And if we ’ re not clever enough perhaps the Vicar can .

div.stage: JOHN shakes his head without speaking .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Don ’ t you want to believe in God , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s pause . KATE comes in to announce DR. MACFARLANE . This is a rather eccentric old man , with long white hair , small , with rosy cheeks . He is an old-fashioned country doctor , and wears rather shabby black clothes and carries a rusty silk hat in his hand . There is in him something of the gentleman farmer and something of the apothecary of a former day .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Dr. Macfarlane .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh ! I ’ d forgotten for the moment .With a smile of welcome .We ’ ve been expecting you .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Shaking hands with the two ladies .I ’ ve been busy this morning .To JOHN .And how are you , John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sitting up and taking nourishment , thank you .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You look none the worse for all your adventures . A little older , perhaps .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , of course , you ’ ve not seen John before .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: No . My wife saw him yesterday in church , but unfortunately I couldn ’ t go . I had to see a patient .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The same patient ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ ve had to see a patient at about eleven every Sunday morning for the last twenty-five years . I was wondering if it was the same one .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: If it is , I certainly deserve praise for keeping the undertakers at bay so long .Going up to the COLONELAnd how are you feeling to-day , Colonel ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m feeling pretty well , thank you . Have you had a letter from that fellow in Canterbury ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Well , what does he say ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You military gentlemen , you want to go so fast .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Have you brought the letter with you ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: It ’ s very technical . Saving your presence , I don ’ t think any of you would make head or tail of it . Now , Mrs. Wharton , my dear , shall you and I go for a little stroll in your beautiful garden , and we ’ ll have a talk about this old tyrant .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: What ’ s the object of that ? Evelyn will only tell me everything you ’ ve said the moment you ’ re gone . She ’ s never been able to keep anything from me in her life .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You must have patience with me . I ’ m an old man , and I like to do things in my own way .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Well , I ’ m no chicken , and I ’ m not going to stand any of your nonsense . Tell us straight out what the doctor says and be damned to you . I beg your pardon , my dear , but I have to talk to the old fool in the only way he understands .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Very rough , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The gentlest pirate who ever cut a throat .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You know , you ’ re a transparent old fraud , Doctor . The moment you came in I saw you had some bad news for me . You were expecting to find Evelyn alone .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: This is the hour at which all self-respecting retired colonels are reading the Times in their study .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: What does Dr. Keller say ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I suppose he wants an operation . It ’ s a nuisance but , with God ’ s help , I can go through with it .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Well , I suppose you ’ d have to know sooner or later . Let these young people clear out and we ’ ll talk it all over quietly .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Nonsense . John is my son and Sylvia is almost my daughter . What concerns me concerns them , I fancy . Why , you couldn ’ t make more fuss if I ’ d only got a month to live .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Hesitating .Do you want me to tell you the whole thing now — just like this ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Yes . You don ’ t think I ’ m afraid to hear the worst . Whatever it is , I hope I have the pluck to bear it like a Christian and a gentleman .

div.stage: There is a pause .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You ’ re quite right . I have bad news for you . Dr. Keller confirms my diagnosis . I was pretty sure of it , but I didn ’ t want to believe it . I thought I might be mistaken .... I ’ m afraid you ’ re very ill indeed . You must be extremely careful .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: George !

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Come , come , my dear , don ’ t get in a state . And does he recommend an operation ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Startled .Do you mean to say that .... But I don ’ t feel so bad as all that . Now and then I have attacks of pain , but then ... you don ’ t mean to say you think I ’ m going to die ? For God ’ s sake tell me the truth .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: My dear old friend !

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You mean I ’ ve got a fatal disease . Can — can nothing be done ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I don ’ t know about that . There ’ s always something that can be done .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: But a cure , I mean . Can ’ t I be cured ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: If you want the truth really , then I ’ m afraid I can hold out no hope of that .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: How long d ’ you give me ?Trying to laugh .I suppose you ’ re not going to grudge me a year or two ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Pretending to take it lightly .Oh , you can be quite sure we ’ ll keep you alive as long as we can .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ ve got a wonderful physique , father . My own impression is that you ’ ll make fools of the doctors and live for another twenty years .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Medicine isn ’ t an exact science like surgery . It ’ s a doctor ’ s duty to tell a patient the truth when he asks for it , but if I were a patient I would always take it with a grain of salt .

div.stage: The COLONEL looks at him suspiciously .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You ’ re keeping something from me . If it was only that , why did you want to see Evelyn alone ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Well , some people are very nervous about themselves . I wasn ’ t quite sure if you ’ d better know or not . I thought I ’ d talk it over with her .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Am I in immediate danger of death ? For God ’ s sake , tell me . It would be cruel to leave me in ignorance .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Please answer quite frankly , doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: After a pause .I think if you have any arrangements to make , it would be wise if you made them soon .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Then it ’ s not a question of a year or two even ? Is it months or weeks ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I don ’ t know . No one can tell .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: You ’ re treating me like a child .With sudden rage .Confound you , sir , I order you to tell me .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: It may be at any time .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: With a sudden cry of terror .Evelyn ! Evelyn !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , my dear ! My dear husband !

div.stage: She takes him in her arms as though to protect him .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Why did you force me to tell you ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: In a terrified whisper .Oh , Evelyn ! Evelyn !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: To the others .Please go .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: To SYLVIA .Come . They want to be alone . Dr. Macfarlane , will you come into the garden for a few minutes ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Of course I will . Of course .

div.stage: They go out . COLONEL and MRS. WHARTON are left alone . For a moment they are silent .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Perhaps it isn ’ t true , my dear .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s true . I know it ’ s true now .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s so hard . I wish it were I instead . I ’ d be so glad to take your place , darling .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: We ’ ve been so happy together , Evelyn .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: We have very much to be grateful for .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , Evelyn , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , my dear , I ’ m so sorry for you . I ’ m so dreadfully sorry .... I think you ’ re very brave . If I ’ d been told like that I — I should have broken down .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: It was so unexpected .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Trying to comfort him .I ’ m thankful that your faith has always been so bright and clear . What a comfort that is now , darling , what an immense consolation !She draws him more closely to her .You ’ re throwing aside these poor rags of mortality to put on a heavenly raiment . It is what we ’ ve always kept in our minds , isn ’ t it ? that this brief life is only a place of passage to the mansions of our dear Father .She feels the dismay in his heart and she strives to give him courage .You ’ ve never hesitated at the call of an earthly leader . You ’ re a good soldier ; it ’ s a Heavenly Leader that ’ s calling you now . Christ is holding out His loving arms to you .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Evelyn — I don ’ t want to die .

div.stage: THE END OF THE FIRST ACT .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: The Scene is the same as in the preceding Act .
Two days have passed . It is Wednesday afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON is sitting by a little table , looking reflectively in
sp.p: front of her . On the table is a work-basket , and by the side of this a baby ’ s shirt that she is making . A fire is alight in the grate . After a minute , JOHN comes in . She looks up at him with a pleasant smile . He goes to her and puts his hand on her shoulder . She gently pats his hand .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Are you idling , mother ? It ’ s not often I catch you giving the devil an opportunity .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Isn ’ t it wicked of me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What is this you ’ re up to ? What in heaven ’ s name are you making a baby ’ s shirt for ? Hang it all , I ’ m not married yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Pretending to be a little shocked .Don ’ t be naughty , John . It ’ s for poor Annie Black ’ s baby .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Who ’ s she ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: She was engaged to Edward Driffield , the carpenter ’ s second man , and they were going to be married next time he came home on leave . He ’ s been killed , and she ’ s expecting a baby .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Poor thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: The Pooles are looking after her . You see , she had nowhere to go , and they didn ’ t want her to have to go to the Workhouse , so Mrs. Poole has taken her in at the Vicarage . And I said I ’ d make all the baby ’ s things .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Affectionately .You ’ re a nice old mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Don ’ t you think it was good of the Pooles ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , charming .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: They ’ re coming here this afternoon , John . I wanted the Vicar to see your father .... I haven ’ t told your father they ’ re coming .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Haven ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He ’ s rather sensitive just now . It ’ s quite natural , isn ’ t it ? And I didn ’ t know exactly how he ’ d take it . I thought if Mrs. Poole came too it would look as though it were just a friendly visit . And perhaps the Vicar will have an opportunity to say a few words to your father .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Smiling .I take it that you want me to help you to leave them alone together .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I hate doing anything underhand , John , but I think it would help your father so much if he could have a little private talk with the Vicar .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you suggest it to him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I didn ’ t like to . I was afraid he ’ d be vexed . I thought he ’ d suggest it himself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Very tenderly .Don ’ t distress yourself , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ m trying not to think of it , John . My only hope is that the end may come without suffering .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wasn ’ t thinking of that .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: After a moment ’ s pause .I don ’ t know what you mean , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , you do . You only have to look in father ’ s face .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I really don ’ t understand .Almost vehemently .You ’ re wrong , John . He suffers much more pain than you think . That ’ s what gives him that look .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gravely .It ’ s fear that ’ s in his face , mother , the fear of death . You know it just as well as I do .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With dismay .I was so hoping that no one would know but me . It tears my heart . And I can do nothing . And he ’ s so strange . Sometimes he looks at me almost as though I were his enemy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He doesn ’ t want to die , does he ? At the bottom of his heart is envy because you can go on living .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Have you noticed that ? I tried not to see it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Don ’ t be angry with him or disappointed . You know , it ’ s a hard thing to die for all of us . Generally one ’ s vitality is lowered so that life seems rather a burden , and it ’ s not very hard then to make a seemly end . But poor father ’ s got something much more difficult to face .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He ’ s been supported all his life by his confidence in the great truths of our religion . Oh , John , it ’ s so dreadful that just at this moment , when he must put them all to the test , he should falter . It ’ s almost a betrayal of the God who loves him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear , you can ’ t imagine that God won ’ t understand ? What do these last weeks matter beside a life that has been cheerful and innocent , devout , unselfish , and dutiful ? We were talking about it the other day , don ’ t you remember ? And I claimed that a man should be judged by what he believed and did in the heyday of his strength , and not by what was wrung from him in a moment of anguish . Pray that God may give my father courage and resignation .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: How can you ask me to pray , John , when you don ’ t believe in God ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Pray all the same , my dear , and for me too .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose I shall survive your father very long , dear . Husbands and wives who ’ ve been so much to one another as we have don ’ t often make a very good job of separation . I ’ m so glad to think that you ’ ll have Sylvia .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia ’ s a good girl , isn ’ t she ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: When you were away I was dreadfully anxious on my own account , of course , but I was anxious on hers too . She ’ s had a very hard time with her mother , and there ’ s been dreadfully little money , only their pensions ; if anything had happened to you , when her mother died she would have had practically nothing . You ’ ve been engaged so long and she ’ s not very young any more . It ’ s not likely that anyone else would have wanted to marry her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mother darling , you ’ re being terribly sentimental now .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With comic indignation .I ’ m not , John . You don ’ t know what it is for a penniless woman to be quite alone in the world when she ’ s lost her youth .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes , I do . But the tears needn ’ t come into your eyes , because Sylvia and I are going to be married and her future is quite adequately provided for .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: She ’ s the only girl I ’ ve ever known that I could bear to think of your marrying .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , as she ’ s the only girl I ever knew that I could bear to marry , we ’ re both quite satisfied .

div.stage: KATE enters , followed by MRS. LITTLEWOOD .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mrs. Littlewood .

div.stage: Exit KATE .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Kissing MRS. WHARTON .How do you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: How are you , my dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: To JOHN .I brought you a wedding present , John .

div.stage: She hands him a small case in which is a pearl pin .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , I say , that is splendid of you . Just look , mother . Isn ’ t it a ripper ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: It was Archie ’ s , you know . He always used to be so proud of it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It ’ s awfully good of you to give me something that belonged to him .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: That is nice of you , Charlotte .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Nonsense . It wasn ’ t any use to me any more . I thought it much better that John should have it than that it should lie in a safe . They tell me pearls go yellow if they ’ re not worn .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: John , dear , go and smoke a cigarette in the garden . I want to have a chat with Mrs. Littlewood .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right , mother .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Do you know that I ’ m thinking of letting my house ? I only kept it so that the boys should have a home to come to when they had a holiday , and now that they ’ re both dead , I think I shall find it more amusing to live in London . I shall join a bridge club .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Charlotte , what does it mean ? Why do you talk like that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: My dear , why shouldn ’ t I join a bridge club ?With a smile .At my age it ’ s surely quite respectable .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ m bewildered . Don ’ t you want me to talk of your boys ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Drily .If you feel you really must pour out your sympathy , you may ; but I don ’ t know that I particularly want it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No one can understand you . You ’ ve behaved so strangely since you came back from France .... I think it was dreadful of you to go to the theatre when the poor lad was hardly cold in his grave . You seem to think of nothing but bridge .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I suppose different people take things in different ways .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I wonder if you ’ re quite in your right mind .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Somewhat amused .Yes , I saw you wondered that .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: If you only knew how eager I am to help you . But you won ’ t let me come near you . We ’ ve known one another for more than thirty years , Charlotte . Why do you put up a stone wall between us ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Gently , as though she were talking to a child .My dear , don ’ t worry your kind heart . If I wanted your help I would come to you at once . But I don ’ t . I really don ’ t .

div.stage: MRS. WHARTON hears her husband ’ s step on the stairs .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Here is George .Going to the window .You can come in when you want to , John .

div.stage: The COLONEL comes into the room . His face is a little whiter than it was two days ago , and there is in his eyes every now and then a haunted look .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Charlotte Littlewood is here , George .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: So I see . How do you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: You ’ re not looking quite up to the mark to-day , Colonel .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: That ’ s a cheering thing to say to a man . I ’ m feeling pretty well .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I was thinking he was looking much better the last day or two .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I presume it ’ s not on my account that you ’ ve lit the fire on a day like this .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No , I feel a little chilly . You always forget that I ’ m not as young as I was , George .

div.stage: The COLONEL sits down in an arm-chair and MRS. WHARTON takes a couple of cushions .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Let me put them behind you , darling .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake don ’ t fuss me , Evelyn . If I want cushions I ’ m perfectly capable of getting them for myself .

div.stage: JOHN enters with SYLVIA and hears the last two speeches .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Come , come , father , you mustn ’ t spoil mother . She ’ s waited on us both for thirty years . Don ’ t let her get into bad habits at her time of life .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , Sylvia , we didn ’ t expect to see you to-day . You said you ’ d be too busy .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I felt I must just look in and see how you all were .

div.stage: The COLONEL gives her a suspicious look . She kisses MRS. WHARTON and MRS. LITTLEWOOD and the COLONEL .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Showing SYLVIA the pearl pin .Look what Mrs. Littlewood has given me . Makes it worth while being married , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , how lovely !

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: You ’ ll find a little present waiting for you when you get home .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: How exciting ! I shall run all the way back .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Now you ’ re here you ’ d better stay to tea , darling .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I really can ’ t . I ’ ve got so much to do at home .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense . You ’ ve got nothing to do at all . We ’ re not going to dream of letting you go .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Remember that you ’ ll have me always from to-morrow on . Don ’ t you think you could well spare me to-day ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Tiresome creature . Though I must say it ’ s rather pleasing .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I never saw two young people who were so thoroughly satisfied with one another as you are .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Putting his arm round SYLVIA ’ S waist .But I ’ m not in the least satisfied with Sylvia . I should like her to have jet black hair and eyes like sloes .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What are sloes , idiot ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t know , but I ’ ve read about them from my youth up .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Colonel , d ’ you know that on my way here through the fields , I actually saw a rabbit ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I hear there ’ s absolutely nothing on the place now , father .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: No , the vermin ’ s been allowed to increase so . There are one or two cock pheasants round the house and that ’ s about all . I don ’ t know what next season — but after all , I needn ’ t worry myself about next season . That ’ ll be your trouble , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wish I had as much chance of getting a shot at those cock pheasants as you have .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: By George , I wish I were twenty years younger . I ’ d take my chance of being shot by a German . It ’ s a bit better than dying like a rat in a trap .

div.stage: KATE enters to announce the VICAR and MRS. POOLE .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Mr. and Mrs. Poole .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: How do you do ?

div.stage: There are general greetings . The COLONEL looks at them and from them to his wife , suspiciously . The POOLES are rather cold with MRS. LITTLEWOOD .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: How do you do ? It ’ s good of you to have come . Sit down .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Well , Sylvia , are you all ready for to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: More or less .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: We thought you might intend to postpone the wedding for a few days .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: They ’ ve waited long enough . Why should they wish to do that ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Hastily .I told Mrs. Poole yesterday that I didn ’ t think I could possibly get everything arranged by to-morrow .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I see that my wife has told you that I ’ m not very well .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Oh , aren ’ t you , Colonel ? I ’ m so sorry to hear that .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: She told me this morning after Communion that you weren ’ t quite up to the mark these days .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I remember in Egypt , when a horse or a mule sickened , the vultures used to gather round out of an empty sky . Most remarkable .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: George , what are you saying ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: With a bitter chuckle .Did Evelyn ask you to come and minister to me ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: It ’ s not very unnatural that when I hear you ’ re ill I should like to come and see you . And , of course , it does happen to be one of the duties of my office .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t know why Evelyn should think I want to be molly-coddled out of the world like an old woman . I ’ ve faced death before . I don ’ t suppose anyone wants to die before he must , but when my time comes I hope to face it like a gentleman and a soldier .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , that I should live to hear my own father talking through his hat . Don ’ t you believe a word those rotten old doctors say . You ’ ll live to bully your devoted family for another twenty years .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Don ’ t talk nonsense to me , John . You all treat me like a child . No one must cross me . I must be petted and spoilt and amused and humoured . God damn it , you never let me forget it for a minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Shall we go for a little turn in the garden ? The sun is out now .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: If you like . I shall stay here . I ’ m chilly .

lg.l: A stroll would do you good , George . The Vicar was asking how the new
Buff Orpingtons were getting on .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: With a chuckle .You ’ re very transparent , my poor Evelyn . When I want to have a chat with the Vicar I ’ ll let him know .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Who has been watching the scene with some amusement .Why don ’ t you have a game of piquet with me , Colonel ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I haven ’ t played piquet for years . I will with pleasure . Where are the cards , Evelyn ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ ll get them for you .

div.stage: She gets cards from a drawer , and puts them on the card table . The COLONEL sits down at the table and sorts the piquet cards out of the pack .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I called on you on Monday , Mrs. Littlewood .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: So I heard .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I was told you were not at home . As I walked away it was impossible for me not to see that you were in your garden .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: It ’ s inadequately protected from the road .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I was rather hurt . I ’ m not aware that there ’ s been anything in my behaviour since I came here to justify you in treating me with discourtesy . Our relations have always been more than cordial .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I didn ’ t wish to see you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: So much as that I had the intelligence to infer . But I felt it my duty not to allow pique to interfere with the due discharge of my office . I had various things to say to you which I thought you should hear , so yesterday I called again , and again was told you were out .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Coolly .I didn ’ t wish to see you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: May I ask why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Well , I suppose you wanted to talk about my boy . I didn ’ t think your conversation could give him back to me .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Don ’ t you think I could have helped you to bear your loss ? I think I could have found in my heart words to persuade you to resignation . I might at least have offered you my sympathy .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I ’ m sorry to seem ungracious , but I don ’ t want your sympathy .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Your attitude amazes me .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: If we didn ’ t all know how devoted you were to your sons , one might really think you were indifferent to their loss .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Reflectively .No , I ’ m not exactly indifferent .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Since you won ’ t see me alone , I must say things to you here and now which I should rather have kept for your private ear . I have a right to remonstrate with you because your behaviour is a scandal to my parish .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: With a smile .Oh , I beg your pardon . I thought it was my welfare you were concerned with . If it ’ s that of the parish , pray say anything you like .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Flushing , but not to be put off .I think it was horrible to go to a music-hall on the very day you had returned from your son ’ s grave in France . But that was in London , and you outraged nobody but yourself . What you do here is different . This is a very small place , and it ’ s shameful that you should give parties and go about from house to house playing cards .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: It seems so heartless not to wear mourning .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Rather flippantly , to prevent the conversation from growing too awkward .Why ? I certainly should hate anyone to wear mourning for me .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You give all and sundry the impression that you ’ re perfectly callous . What influence do you think such a thing may have on these young fellows in the village who have to risk their lives with all the other brave lads at the front ? You take from them the comfort that we at home love them and if they fall will hold their memories gratefully in our hearts for ever .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have thought the eccentricity of one old woman could matter very much to anyone .She pauses and looks out into the open for a moment , and then makes up her mind to speak . She speaks quite quietly , almost to herself .When they sent for me and I went over to France I wasn ’ t very anxious , because I knew that God , who had taken my eldest son , would leave my second . You see , he was the only one I had left . And when I got there and found he was dead — I suddenly felt that it didn ’ t matter .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , what do you mean ? How can you say such a thing ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Don ’ t , mother . Let her go on .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I didn ’ t feel that anything very much mattered . It ’ s difficult to explain exactly what I mean . I feel that I have nothing more to do with the world and the world has nothing more to do with me . So far as I ’ m concerned it ’ s a failure . You know I wasn ’ t very happy in my married life , but I loved my two sons , and they made everything worth while , and now they ’ re gone . Let others take up the — the adventure . I step aside .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You ’ ve suffered too much , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: No , the strange thing is that I haven ’ t suffered very much . Don ’ t you know how sometimes one has a horrid dream and knows one ’ s only dreaming all the time ?To the VICAR , with the same good temper , almost amused .You ’ re surprised that I should go to the theatre . Why ? To me , it ’ s no more unreal a spectacle than life . Life does seem to me just like a play now . I can ’ t take it very seriously . I feel strangely detached . I have no ill-feeling for my fellow-creatures , but you don ’ t seem very real to me or very important . Why shouldn ’ t I play bridge with you ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Oh , but , my dear , my dear , there ’ s one reality that you can never escape from . There ’ s God .

div.stage: A flash passes behind the old woman ’ s eyes . She rises and puts out her hand as though to ward off a blow .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I don ’ t think we ’ ll talk about God if you please . I prefer to play piquet .

div.stage: She sits down at the table at which the COLONEL has already taken his seat .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Do you play four hands or six to the game ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Four — and double the first and last . It makes it more exciting .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Shall we cut for deal ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Cutting .You ’ re not likely to beat that .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I suppose in the Vicar ’ s presence we daren ’ t play for money ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: We ’ ll pretend he ’ s not there . Will a shilling a hundred suit you ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I don ’ t think that ’ ll break either of us .
