div.stage: KATE enters , followed by DR. MACFARLANE .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Dr. Macfarlane .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .So nice of you to come in .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: How is the Colonel to-day ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Playing piquet .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ re coming to-morrow , aren ’ t you , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Of course I am . I brought you both into the world . I have almost a personal interest in seeing you made one flesh .

lg.l: It ’ s many a long day since you ’ ve been inside a church ,
Doctor .
Since you clerical gentlemen left off threatening me with eternal flames
I feel justified in following my own inclinations in the matter .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Chaffing him .But we still believe in annihilation .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I ’ m willing to take my chance of that . It has no terrors for a man who ’ s not had a holiday for twenty years .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You ’ re not an irreligious man . I don ’ t know why you don ’ t come to church .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Shall I tell you ? Because after repeated experiment I ’ ve reached the conclusion that I ’ m not a whit the better for it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ ll have to give him up , Vicar . He ’ s a stubborn old thing . He takes advantage of the fact that he ’ s the only doctor within ten miles who won ’ t kill you so long as he can make seven and sixpence a visit by keeping you alive .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Do you mean to say that our Church doesn ’ t believe any longer in eternal punishment ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , father , hell has always left me perfectly cold . You and I are quite safe . You see , mother would never be happy in heaven without us , and God couldn ’ t refuse her anything she asked .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Affectionately .John , what nonsense you talk .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I sometimes think the modern Church has been very rash in surrendering a belief which has the authority of Our Lord himself . How many sinners have been brought to repentance by the fear of everlasting punishment !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That rather suggests calling down fire from heaven to light a cigar .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: That may be funny , but I don ’ t see the point of it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Well , I should have thought it hardly required anything so tremendous as eternity to deal with human wickedness . I suppose sin is due to a man ’ s character , which he can ’ t help , or to his ignorance , for which he isn ’ t to blame .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: In fact , to your mind sin is all moonshine .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I think it a pity that Christianity has laid so much stress on it . We assert in church that we ’ re miserable sinners , but I don ’ t think we mean it , and what ’ s more I don ’ t think we are .

lg.l: We are conceived in sin , and sin is part of our inheritance . Why did
Christ die if not to atone for the sin of men ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In war one gets to know very intimately all sorts of queer people . I don ’ t suppose I shall ever know any men so well as I knew the men in my company . They were honest and brave and cheerful , unselfish , good fellows ; perhaps they swore a good deal , and they got drunk if they had the chance , and they had the glad eye for a pretty girl . But do you think they were sinners for that ? I don ’ t .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Look in your own heart and say if you are not conscious of grievous , terrible sin .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Frankly , I ’ m not .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you mean to say that you have nothing to reproach yourself with ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ ve done a certain number of things which I think were rather foolish , but I can ’ t think of anything that I ’ m particularly ashamed of .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you mean to tell me that you ’ ve always been perfectly chaste ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m normal and healthy . I ’ ve been no more chaste than any other man of my age .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: And isn ’ t that sin ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t think so . I think it ’ s human nature .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We ’ re arguing at cross-purposes . If when you say “ white ” you mean what the rest of the world calls “ black ,” all words are futile .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .The singular thing is that if I ’ d answered your question with a “ yes ,” you would probably have thought me a liar or a fool .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: This terrible condition of humanity , which seems to cry out against the very idea either of man ’ s dignity , or of God ’ s justice , has but one explanation , and that is sin .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ re referring to the war ? It needs some explaining , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Every Christian must have asked himself why God allows the infamous horror of war . I ’ m told the padres are constantly being asked by the brave lads at the Front why the Almighty allows it to continue . I can ’ t blame anyone for being puzzled . I ’ ve wrestled with the question long and anxiously .... I can ’ t believe that God would leave His children to suffer without a clue to His intention .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: The ways of God are inscrutable . How can we tell what are the aims of the eternal ? We only know that they are good .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Meanwhile men are being killed like flies , their wives and mothers are left desolate , and their children fatherless .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You mustn ’ t forget exactly what is meant by “ Almighty .” It means not so much able to do all things as powerful over all things .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ah , the padre of my regiment told me that . I may be very stupid , but I think the distinction rather fine . For the plain man the difficulty remains . Either God can ’ t stop the war even if He wants to , or He can stop it and won ’ t .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: In my opinion there can be no hesitation . It is written : “ Not a sparrow shall fall on the ground without your Father .”

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Remember that we have free will and God makes use of our free will to punish us and to teach us and to make us more worthy of His grace and mercy . Man , born in sin , justly brought this long-drawn disaster on himself as surely as Adam brought on himself the divine punishment which we all inherit .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If I saw two small boys fighting I ’ d separate them , even though one was a lazy little beggar and the other had stolen Farmer Giles ’ apples . I wouldn ’ t sit by and let them seriously hurt one another so that they should be better boys in future .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: But you speak as though all this suffering must be useless . We all know how suffering can purify and elevate . I ’ ve seen it myself over and over again .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: People say that . They ’ re generally thinking of elderly ladies in comfortable circumstances who with the aid of a very good doctor show a becoming resignation in a chronic disease .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should like some of those people who talk about the purifying influence of suffering to have a mouthful of gas and see how they liked it .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: The war is terrible . Its cruelty is terrible . The suffering it has caused is terrible . There is only one explanation for it ; and that is the loving kindness and the infinite mercy of our heavenly Father .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Can you bring yourself to believe that ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: We were given over to drunkenness and lust , to selfishness and flippancy and pride . It needed this tremendous trial to purify us . It will be a nobler England that comes out of the furnace . Oh , I pray to God that all this blood may wash our souls clean so that we may once more be found worthy in His sight .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Amen .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You must evidently know much more about it than I do . When the men in my company did things I thought were wrong I used to jolly them a bit . I fancy I got better results than if I ’ d bashed them on the head with a sledge-hammer .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Sin began with the beginning of the human story and has continued through all its course . The motive of the divine redemption lies in the fact that men , though created for so lofty a purpose , have plunged so deep into sin and have so deeply defaced in themselves the image of God , that only the self-sacrificing act of God in redeeming them can raise them from ruin .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wish you ’ d been a company-commander and had seen how gaily a man can give his life for his friend .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: But I know , my dear boy , I know . And do you think God will be unmindful of their sacrifice ? I pray and believe that they will find mercy in His sight . I am sure He is more ready to pardon than to punish . After all , our Lord came to call sinners to repentance , and who should know better than the Ministers of God that to err is human , to forgive , divine ?

div.stage: The piquet players have played their game with a certain distraction , and during the last few speeches have made no more pretence of playing at all . MRS. LITTLEWOOD has listened attentively . Now she puts down her cards , gets up , and walks up to the VICAR .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: And who is going to forgive God ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With horror .Charlotte !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: With grave disapproval .Don ’ t you think that is rather blasphemous ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Quietly and deliberately at first , but with ever-increasing excitement .Ever since I was a child I ’ ve served God with all my might , and with all my heart , and with all my soul . I ’ ve tried always to lead my life in accordance with His will . I never forgot that I was as nothing in His sight . I ’ ve been weak and sinful , but I ’ ve tried to do my duty .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Yes , dear , you ’ ve been an example to us all .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Taking no notice .Honestly , I ’ ve done everything I could that I thought was pleasing in His sight . I ’ ve praised Him and magnified His name . You ’ ve heard that my husband deserted me when I ’ d borne him two children , and I was left alone . I brought them up to be honest , upright and God-fearing men . When God took my eldest son I wept , but I turned to the Lord and said : “ Thy will be done .” He was a soldier , and he took his chance , and he died in a good cause .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: A great and a good cause .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: But why did God take my second ? He was the only one I had left , the only comfort of my old age , my only joy , the only thing I had to prevent me from seeing that my life had been wasted and it would have been better if I had never been born . I haven ’ t deserved that . When a horse has served me long and faithfully till he ’ s too old to work I have the right to send him to the knacker ’ s yard , but I don ’ t , I put him out to grass . I wouldn ’ t treat a dog as my Father has treated me . I ’ ve been cheated . You say that God will forgive us our sins , but who is going to forgive God ? Not I . Never . Never !

div.stage: In a height of frenzy she rushes out into the garden . There is silence in the room .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Don ’ t be angry with her , Vicar . She ’ s beside herself with grief .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: She ’ ll come back . She ’ s like a petulant child that has been thwarted for its good . It cries and stamps , but in a little while it throws itself into its mother ’ s arms , and begs , all tears , for forgiveness .

lg.stage: With a little sigh of relief .
lg.l: I knew you ’ d take it like that ,
Norman . You ’ re so tolerant and broad-minded .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I think I see my way to help her , poor soul .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wonder how . Your only explanation of evil is sin . I daresay you can get people to acknowledge that they ’ ve deserved their own suffering . But you ’ ll never prevent them from being revolted at the suffering of others . Why is evil permitted in the world by an all-good God ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I can hardly hope that any answer of mine will satisfy you . By God ’ s grace I am a Christian . You are an atheist .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s embarrassment . JOHN realises that his mother or SYLVIA has repeated what he has said .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That suggests a very dogmatic attitude . I don ’ t see how anyone can positively assert that there is no God . It would be as reasonable as to assert that there ’ s nothing on the other side of a wall that you can ’ t look over .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Do you believe in God ?

lg.l: I don ’ t think it ’ s quite your business to ask me .
Wasn ’ t it St. Paul who said : “ Be not zealous overmuch .”

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: You can ’ t be unaware that by certain statements of yours the other day you gave the greatest pain to those nearest and dearest to you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What you said made me very unhappy , John . I didn ’ t know what to do . I went to the Vicar and asked his advice .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Don ’ t you think that a man ’ s belief is his own affair ? I don ’ t want to interfere with other people ’ s . Why can ’ t they leave me quietly to mine ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It can ’ t be entirely your affair , John . You and I propose to be married to-morrow . It ’ s only reasonable that I should know exactly how you stand in a matter that concerns me so closely .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I hadn ’ t thought of that . I daresay there ’ s something in what you say . I ’ m willing to do my best to explain to you and to father and mother . But I really think we needn ’ t drag strangers in .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I think it would be much better if you would talk with the Vicar , John . We don ’ t pretend to be very clever , and it wouldn ’ t mean much if you asked us questions that we couldn ’ t answer .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: When you ’ re ill you send for a doctor , he prescribes for you , and you get well .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .What do you think of that , doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: It is an idea that we do our little best to spread about the world .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Anyhow , you take a doctor ’ s advice and you don ’ t argue with him . Why ? Because he ’ s an expert , and you presume that he knows his business . Why should the science of the immortal soul be a less complicated affair than the science of the perishable body ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Look upon us as very silly , old-fashioned people , and be kind to us . If various doubts are troubling you , put them frankly before the Vicar . Perhaps he can help you .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Sincerely .Believe me , I ’ ll do everything in my power .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: And if he can convince you that you were wrong , I know you too well to dream that pride would stop you from confessing it . It would give us such heartfelt joy , my dear , if you could believe again as you did when you were a little child and used to say your prayers kneeling on my lap .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I really think I can help you . Won ’ t you forget that I ’ m a stranger and let me try ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Perhaps you ’ d like me to leave you . I was only waiting till the Colonel had finished his game so that I might take him upstairs and have a look at him . But I can come back later .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t mind your staying at all .To the Vicar .What is it you wish to ask me ?

lg.l: Do you believe in the God in whose name you were baptised into the
Church ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: That at all events is frank and honest . But aren ’ t you a little out of date ? One of the most gratifying occurrences of recent years has been the revival of belief among thoughtful men .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I should have thought it was a revival of rhetoric rather than of religion . I ’ m not enormously impressed by the cultured journalist who uses God to balance a sentence or adorn a phrase .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: But it hasn ’ t only been among educated men . Not the least remarkable thing about the war has been the return of our brave lads at the Front to the faith which so many of us thought they had forgotten . What is your explanation of that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Fear with the most part . Perplexity with the rest .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Don ’ t you think it very rash to reject a belief that all the ablest men in the world have held since the dawn of history ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: When you ’ re dealing with a belief , neither the number nor the ability of those who hold it makes it a certainty . Only proof can do that .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Are you quite sure that at the bottom of your heart it ’ s not conceit that makes you think differently from the rest of us ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: No , my dear , let us not ascribe unworthy motives to our antagonist .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Smiling .At all events , not yet .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What makes you think that the existence of God can ’ t be proved ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I suppose at this time of day people wouldn ’ t still be proving it if proof were possible .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: My dear fellow , the fact that there is no people on the face of the earth , however barbarous and degraded , without some belief in God , is the most conclusive proof you can want .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What of ? It ’ s conclusive proof that the desire for His existence is universal . It ’ s not proof that the desire is fulfilled .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I see you have the usual Rationalistic arguments at your fingers ’ ends . Believe me , they ’ re old friends , and if I ’ ve answered them once I ’ ve answered them a thousand times .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And have you ever convinced anyone who wasn ’ t convinced before ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I can ’ t make the blind to see , you know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I wonder that hasn ’ t suggested to you a very obvious conclusion .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why , that arguments are futile . Think for a minute . You don ’ t believe in God for any of the reasons that are given for His existence . You believe in Him because with all your heart you feel that He exists . No argument can ever touch that feeling . The heart is independent of logic and its rules .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I daresay there ’ s something in what you say .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , it ’ s the same with me . If you ask me why I don ’ t believe in the existence of God I suppose I can give you a certain number of reasons , but the real one , the one that gives all the others their force , is that I feel it in my heart .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What is the cause of your feeling ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m sure you ’ ll think it very insufficient . I had a friend and he was killed .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I ’ m afraid one must be prepared to lose one ’ s friends in a war like this .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I daresay it ’ s very silly and sentimental of me . One gets used to one ’ s pals dying . Someone says to you : “ So-and-So ’ s knocked out .” And you answer : “ Is he really ? Poor chap .” And you don ’ t think very much more about it . Robbie Harrison wasn ’ t quite an ordinary man .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I was afraid you ’ d feel his death very much . You never mentioned it in your letters . I felt it was because you couldn ’ t bear to speak of it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He was one of those lucky beggars who do everything a little better than anybody else . He was clever and awfully nice-looking and amusing . I never knew anyone who loved life so much as he did .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Yes , I remember his saying to me once : “ Isn ’ t it ripping to be alive ?”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But there was something more in him than that . He had one quality which was rather out of the ordinary . It ’ s difficult to explain what it was like . It seemed to shine about him like a mellow light . It was like the jolly feeling of the country in May . And do you know what it was ? Goodness . Just goodness . He was the sort of man that I should like to be .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He was a dear .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I was awfully excited when war was declared . I was in India at the time . I moved heaven and earth to get out to the Front . I thought war the noblest sport in the world . I found it a dreary , muddy , dirty , stinking , bloody business . And I suppose Robbie ’ s death was the last straw . It seemed so unjust . I don ’ t know that it was grief so much that I felt as indignation . I was revolted by all the horror and pain and suffering .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: You must have seen some dreadful things .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Perhaps it ’ s Christianity that has shown us the possibility of a higher morality than Christianity teaches . I daresay I ’ m quite wrong . I can only tell you that all that ’ s moral in my soul revolts at the thought of a God who can permit the monstrous iniquity of war . I can ’ t believe that there is a God in heaven .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: But do you realise that if there isn ’ t , the world is meaningless ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That may be . But if there is it ’ s infamous .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: What have you got to put in the place of religion ? What answer can you give to the riddle of the universe ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I may think your answer wrong and yet have no better one to put in its place .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: Have you nothing to tell us at all when we ask you why man is here and what is his destiny ? You are like a rudderless ship in a stormy sea .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I suppose the human race has arisen under the influence of conditions which are part of the earth ’ s history , and under the influence of other conditions it will come to an end . I don ’ t see that there is any more meaning in life than in the statement that two and two are four .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: With suppressed passion .Then you think that all our efforts and struggles , our pain and sorrow , our aims , are senseless ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do you remember our going to the Russian ballet before the war ? I ’ ve never forgotten a certain gesture of one of the dancers . It was an attitude she held for an instant , in the air ; it was the most lovely thing I ever saw in my life ; you felt it could only have been achieved by infinite labour , and the fact that it was so fleeting , like the shadow of a bird flying over a river , made it all the more wonderful . I ’ ve often thought of it since , and it has seemed to me a very good symbol of life .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: John , you can ’ t be serious .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ ll tell you what I mean . Life seems to me like a huge jig-saw puzzle that doesn ’ t make any picture , but if we like we can make little patterns , as it were , out of the pieces .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What is the use of that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: There ’ s no use , and no need . It ’ s merely something we can do for our own satisfaction . Pain and sorrow are some of the pieces that we have to deal with . By making the most of all our faculties , by using all our opportunities , out of the manifold events of life , our deeds , our feelings , our thoughts , we can make a design which is intricate , dignified , and beautiful . And death at one stroke completes and destroys it .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s silence .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: I wonder why you ’ re coming to church to-morrow to be married ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .I think Sylvia would be outraged at the thought of being married in a registry office .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: It ’ s lucky for you the Vicar is broad-minded . A stricter man might think it his duty to refuse the blessing of the Church to an unbeliever .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Anxiously .Vicar , you ’ re not thinking of doing anything like that ?

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I confess the question has crossed my mind .Kindly .I don ’ t think I can bring myself to expose such good Christians as you and Sylvia to such a humiliation .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You need not harass yourself , Vicar . I ’ ve decided not to marry John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Aghast .Sylvia ! Sylvia , you can ’ t mean that !

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I was dreadfully troubled the other day when you told us you ’ d lost your faith , but I hadn ’ t the courage to say anything then . It came as such an awful shock .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But you never made the least sign .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I hadn ’ t time to think it out , but I ’ ve been thinking hard ever since , day and night , and I ’ ve listened very carefully to what you ’ ve said to-day . I can ’ t keep up the pretence any more . I ’ ve quite made up my mind . I won ’ t marry you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But in God ’ s name , why ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You are not the John I loved and promised myself to . It ’ s a different man that has come back from abroad . I have nothing in common with that man .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia , you don ’ t mean to say that you don ’ t care for me any more because on certain matters I don ’ t hold the same views as you ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But those matters are the most important in the world . You talk as though it were a difference of opinion over the colour of our drawing-room curtains . You don ’ t even understand me any more .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How can I understand something that seems absolutely unreasonable to me ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Do you think religion is something I take up with my Prayer-book when I go to church , and put away on a shelf when I get home again ? John , God is a living presence that is always with me . I never at any moment lose the consciousness of that divine love which with infinite mercy tends and protects me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , dear heart , you know me well enough . You know I would never hinder you in the exercise of your religion . I would always treat it with the utmost respect .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: How could we possibly be happy when all that to me is the reason and the beauty of life , to you is nothing but a lie ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With tolerance on both sides , and , I hope , respect , there ’ s no reason why two people shouldn ’ t live peaceably together no matter how different their views are .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: How can I be tolerant when I see you deep in error ? Oh , it ’ s more than error , it ’ s sin . You ’ ve had your choice between light and darkness , and you ’ ve deliberately chosen darkness . You are a deserter . If words mean anything at all you are condemned .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , my dear , a man believes what he can . You don ’ t seriously think that a merciful God is going to punish him because he ’ s unable to believe something that he finds incredible ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No one doubts that Our Lord will have mercy on those who have never had the chance of receiving His teaching . You ’ ve had the chance , and you ’ ve refused to take it . Do you forget the Parable of the Ten Talents ? It is a terrible warning .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: After all , if I ’ m wrong I hurt nobody but myself .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You forget what marriage is . It makes us one flesh . I am bidden to cleave to you and to follow you . How can I , when our souls must ever be separated by an unsurpassable abyss ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Sylvia , this is a dreadfully grave decision you ’ re making . Be careful that you ’ re acting rightly .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia , you can ’ t throw me over like this after we ’ ve been engaged for seven years . It ’ s too heartless .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I don ’ t trust you . I have no hold over you . What have you to aim at beside the satisfaction of your own vulgar appetite ? Sin means nothing to you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear , you don ’ t suppose it ’ s religion that makes a man decent ? If he ’ s kind and honest and truthful it ’ s because it ’ s his nature , not because he believes in God or fears hell .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: We ’ re neither of us very young any more , there ’ s no reason why we should make a mystery of natural things . If we married my greatest hope was that we should have children .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It was mine too .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Have you asked yourself how this would affect them ? Which are they to be , Christians or Agnostics ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: My dear , I promise you I will not interfere with your teaching of them .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Do you mean to say you will stand by while they are taught a pack of worthless lies ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Your faith has been the faith of our people for hundreds of years . In the case of a difference of opinion I could not take it on myself to refuse children instruction in it . When they reach years of discretion they can judge for themselves .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: And supposing they ask you about things ? The story of Our Saviour appeals to children , you know . It ’ s very natural that they should put you questions . What will you answer ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t think you could ask me to say what I thought untrue .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He could always refer them to you , Sylvia dear .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You naturally wouldn ’ t come to church . What sort of an example would you set your children in a matter of which I was impressing on them the enormous importance ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a smile .My dear , surely you ’ re letting a lack of humour cloud a lively intelligence . Vast numbers of excellent churchmen don ’ t go to church , and I ’ m not aware that their children are corrupted by it .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Passionately .You don ’ t understand . You ’ ll never understand . It ’ s a joke to you . It ’ s all over and done with , John . Let me go . I beseech you to let me go .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Half rising from his chair .I feel most awfully ill .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: In alarm .George !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Simultaneously .Father !

div.stage: MRS. WHARTON , JOHN , and the DOCTOR hurry towards him .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: George , are you in pain ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Awful !

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You ’ d better lie down on the sofa .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: No , I ’ d rather go upstairs .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Don ’ t crowd round him .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: I feel as if I were going to die .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Do you think you can manage to walk ?

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: Yes . Help me , Evelyn .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Put your arm round my neck , father .

sp.speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
sp.p: No , it ’ s all right . I can manage .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: We ’ ll get you upstairs and put you to bed .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Come , darling , put all your weight on me .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: That ’ s right . You needn ’ t come , John . You ’ ll only be in the way .

div.stage: MRS. WHARTON and the DOCTOR help the COLONEL out of the room .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: We ’ d better go , Norman .To JOHN .I hope it ’ s nothing very serious .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m sure I hope not .

sp.speaker: MRS. POOLE
sp.p: Please don ’ t bear us a grudge for any of the things Norman or I have said to you to-day . You know , I saw the letter your Colonel wrote to Mrs. Wharton when you were wounded , and I know how splendid you ’ ve been .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , nonsense !

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: I ’ m afraid you may have to go through a good deal of distress in the near future . If you should change your mind in some of the things that we ’ ve talked about this afternoon no one would be more happy than myself .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It ’ s very good of you to say so , but I don ’ t think it likely .

sp.speaker: VICAR
sp.p: One never knows by what paths the Most High will call His creatures to Himself . He is more cunning to save His children than they are to lose themselves . If you listen to the call , come to the Communion Table . I will ask no questions . It will be a joyful day for me if I am privileged to offer you the Blessed Sacrament of Our Lord and Saviour .

div.stage: He stretches out his hand and JOHN takes it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: THE VICAR and MRS. POOLE go into the garden . JOHN turns to SYLVIA .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Is it the question that the Vicar put me when we were talking about sin that has upset you , Sylvia ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , I don ’ t think it was very nice of him to put it . I never thought about the matter . I don ’ t see why I should expect you to be better than other men .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Did you really mean all you said just now ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Every word .

div.stage: She takes off her engagement ring and hands it to him . He does not take it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With deep emotion .Sylvia , I couldn ’ t say it before all those people , it seemed too intimate and private a matter . Doesn ’ t it mean anything to you that I love you ? It ’ s been so much to me in all I ’ ve gone through to think of you . You ’ ve been everything in the world to me . When I was cold and wet and hungry and miserable , I ’ ve thought of you , and it all grew bearable .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry . I can ’ t marry you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How can you be so cold and heartless ? Sylvia , my dear , I love you ! Won ’ t you give it a chance ?

div.stage: She looks at him steadily for a moment . She braces herself for the final effort .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But I don ’ t love you any more , John .

div.stage: She hands him the ring again and he takes it silently .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It ’ s not a very swagger one , is it ? I was none too flush in those days and I didn ’ t want to ask father to help me . I wanted to buy it out of my own money .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ ve worn it for seven years , John .

div.stage: He turns away from SYLVIA and walks over to the fire-place . When SYLVIA sees what he is going to do she makes a gesture as though to prevent him , but immediately controls herself . He stands looking at the fire for a moment , then throws the ring in ; he watches what will happen to it . SYLVIA clutches her heart . She can hardly prevent the sobs which seem to tear her breast .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I think I ’ ll be getting home . John — if your father or mother want me you can send , can ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Looking over his shoulder .Of course . I ’ ll let you know at once .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: In a natural voice .Good-bye , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-bye , Sylvia .

div.stage: He turns back to look at the fire , and she walks slowly out of the room .
THE END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The Scene is the same as in the preceding Acts . It is early morning on the following Wednesday . The dead ashes of yesterday ’ s fire are still in the grate . Not far away is heard the ringing of a church bell to call the faithful to the first service .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON is standing by a table on which is a large basket of
sp.p: white flowers which she had just brought in from the garden . She picks up a rose , and with a faint smile gives it a little caress . SYLVIA comes in from the garden .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: With surprise .Mrs. Wharton !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , Sylvia , is it you ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It startled me to see you there . I came in this way because I saw the door was open and your front door bell ’ s so noisy . I thought if the Colonel was asleep it might wake him .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s early , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes , I ’ m on my way to the early service . I thought I ’ d look in just to ask how the Colonel was . But I didn ’ t expect to see you . I thought Kate or Hannah might be about .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: George is dead , Sylvia .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: In amazement .Mrs. Wharton !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: He died quite peacefully about an hour ago . I ’ ve just been to gather some flowers to put in his room .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Wharton , I ’ m so sorry . I ’ m so dreadfully sorry for you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Patting her hand .Thank you , my dear ; you ’ ve been very kind to us during these days .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Where is John ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I think he must have gone out for a walk . I went to his room a little while ago and he wasn ’ t there . He wanted to sit up with me last night , but I wouldn ’ t let him .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But ... but doesn ’ t John know his father is dead ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No , not yet .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Didn ’ t you call him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I had no idea the end was so near . George wanted to be alone with me , Sylvia . We ’ d been married for thirty-five years , you see . He was conscious almost to the last . He died quite suddenly , like a child going to sleep .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It ’ s such a terrible loss . You poor dear , you must be quite heart-broken .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It ’ s a very great loss , but I ’ m not heart-broken . George is happy and at rest . We should be very poor Christians if the death of those we love made us unhappy . George has entered into eternal life .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Wharton , what a blessed thing it is to have a faith like yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , a very wonderful thing happened last night . I can ’ t feel grief for dear George ’ s death because of the recollection of that . I feel so strange . I feel as though I were walking in an enchanted garden .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I don ’ t know what you mean .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Since that day when George refused to talk with the Vicar I never dared mention the subject . He was not himself . It made me so unhappy . And then last night , soon after Dr. Macfarlane went away , he asked of his own accord for Mr. Poole . The Vicar ’ s a dear , kind man . He ’ d said to me that if ever George asked for him he ’ d come at once , at any hour of the day or night . So I sent for him . He gave George the Holy Sacrament . And Sylvia , a miracle happened .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: A miracle ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No sooner had the bread and the wine touched his lips than he was transfigured . All his — his anxiety left him , and he was once more his dear , good , brave self . He was quite happy to die . It was as though an unseen hand had pulled back a dark curtain of clouds and he saw before him , not night and a black coldness , but a path of golden sunshine that led straight to the arms of God .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ m so glad . I ’ m happy too now .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: The Vicar read the prayers for the dying and then he left us . We talked of the past and of our reunion in a little while . And then he died .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It ’ s wonderful . Yes , it was a miracle .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: All through my life I ’ ve been conscious of the hand of God shaping the destinies of man . I ’ ve never seen His loving mercy more plainly manifest .

div.stage: KATE opens the door and stands on the threshold , but does not come into the room .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: The woman ’ s come , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Very well . I ’ m just coming .

div.stage: KATE goes out and shuts the door behind her . MRS. WHARTON takes up her basket of flowers .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: John will be in immediately , Sylvia . He promised to come and relieve me at half-past eight , so that I might get something to eat . Will you see him ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Wharton , if you wish me to .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Will you tell him that his father is dead ? I know you ’ ll do it very gently .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Wharton , wouldn ’ t you prefer to tell him yourself ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You know he loves you , Sylvia . It would make me so happy if you two could arrive at some understanding . It seems such a pity that the happiness of both of you should be ruined .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I would do anything in the world for John , but I can ’ t sacrifice what is and must be dearer to me even than he .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Can ’ t you teach him to believe ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , I wish I could . I pray for him night and day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I wished afterwards that I ’ d asked him to be present when his father and I received the Communion . I think at that last solemn moment he might have been moved to receive it with us .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: D ’ you think .... Perhaps a miracle would have taken place in him , too . Perhaps he would have believed .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I must go upstairs .

div.stage: An idea seizes SYLVIA , and she gives a strange little gasp . As MRS. WHARTON is about to leave the room she stops her with a sudden question .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Mrs. Wharton ... Mrs. Wharton , do you think the end can ever justify the means ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , what an extraordinary question ! It can never be right to do evil that good may come .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Are you quite sure that that ’ s so always ? After all , no one would hesitate to tell a lie to save another ’ s life .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Perhaps not .With a faint smile .We must thank God that we ’ re not likely to be put in such a position . Why did you ask me that ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I was wondering what one should do if one could only rescue somebody from terrible danger by committing a great sin . Do you think one ought to do it or not ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , you haven ’ t the right to offend God for the sake of anyone in the world .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Not even for the sake of anyone you loved ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Surely not , my dear . And no one who loved you would wish you for a moment to do a wicked thing for his sake .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But take your own case , Mrs. Wharton ; if you saw the Colonel or John in deadly peril wouldn ’ t you risk your life to save them ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With a smile .Of course I should . I should be happy and thankful to have the opportunity . But that ’ s not the same . I should only be risking my life , not my soul .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Almost beside herself .But if their souls were in peril , wouldn ’ t you risk your soul ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , what do you mean ? You seem so excited .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Controlling herself with a great effort .I ? You mustn ’ t pay any attention to me . I haven ’ t been sleeping very well the last three or four nights . I daresay I ’ m a little hysterical .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t you prefer to go home , darling ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , I ’ d like to stay here if you don ’ t mind . I ’ d like to see John .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Very well . I shan ’ t be very long .

div.stage: She goes out . The church bell gives a hurried tinkle and then stops . SYLVIA walks up and down the room and stands still in front of a photograph of JOHN in his uniform . She takes it up and looks at it . Then putting it down she clasps her hands and raises her eyes . She is seen to be praying . She hears a sound in the garden , inclines her head to listen , and goes to the window . She hesitates a moment and then braces herself to a decision . She calls .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: John !

div.stage: He comes , stops for a moment on the threshold , and then walks forward casually .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good morning ! You ’ re very early .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I looked in to ask how your father was .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: When I left him last night he was fairly comfortable . I ’ ll go and find out from mother how he is .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , don ’ t — don ’ t disturb him .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m going to take mother ’ s place in a few minutes . I awoke early , so I went for a walk .... You ’ ve been very good and kind to all of us during these wretched days , Sylvia . I don ’ t know what we should have done without you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ ve been so dreadfully sorry . And you all had so much to bear . It wasn ’ t only the thought that the poor dear couldn ’ t — can ’ t recover , but ... it was so much worse than that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a quick glance at her .I suppose it was inevitable that you should see it too . Somehow I hoped that only I and mother knew .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , John , you can ’ t mind about me . I ’ ve loved your father as though he were my own . Nothing he did could make me love him less .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: He ’ s afraid to die . It ’ s dreadful to see his terror and to be able to do nothing to help him .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Would you do anything to help him if you could ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It ’ s unfortunate that you found it necessary to say what you did about religion . He ’ s always been a very simple man . He always accepted without question the faith in which he was brought up . Perhaps he ’ s not quite so sure now .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense , Sylvia . Father ’ s faith is very much too steady for it to be unsettled by any opinions of mine .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Ordinarily , I dare say . But he ’ s ill , he ’ s in terrible pain , he ’ s not himself . I think perhaps it ’ s a pity you didn ’ t hold your tongue . It ’ s so easy to create doubts and so hard to allay them .

lg.l: That ’ s an awful thought to have put into my head ,
Sylvia . I should never forgive myself if ....

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: If you ’ d believed as we believe , he would have been supported , as it were , by all our faith . It would have made that terrible passage from this life to the life to come a little less terrible . You ’ ve failed him just when he needed you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Indignantly .Oh , Sylvia , how can you say anything so heartless ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Coldly .It ’ s true .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Heaven knows , I know that death isn ’ t easy . You can ’ t think I ’ d be so inhuman as to do anything to make it more difficult ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Except mortify your pride .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Impatiently .What has pride got to do with it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: There was pride in every word you said . Are you sure it ’ s not pride of intellect that ’ s responsible for your change of heart ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Icily .Perhaps . How do you suggest I should mortify it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Well , you see , you can confess your error .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t think it ’ s an error .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: At least you can undo some of the harm you ’ ve done . Do you know what is chiefly tormenting your father ? Your refusal to receive the Holy Communion . He keeps talking about it to your mother . He keeps harping on it . He ’ s dreadfully distressed about it . If you received the Communion , John , it would give your father peace .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia , how can I ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: All your life your father has done everything in the world for you . Nothing ’ s been too good for you . You owe him all your happiness , everything you are and hope to be . Can ’ t you do this one little thing for him ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No , it ’ s out of the question . I really can ’ t . I ’ m awfully sorry .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: How can you be so hard ? It ’ s the last wish he ’ ll ever have in the world . It ’ s your last chance of showing your love for him . Oh , John , show a little mercy to his weakness !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , Sylvia , it would be blasphemous .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What are you talking about ? You don ’ t believe . To you it ’ s merely an idle ceremony . What can it matter to you if you go through a meaningless form ?

lg.l: I ’ ve been a Christian too long . I have a hundred generations of
Christianity behind me .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You never hesitated at coming to church when we were going to be married .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That was different .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: How ? That was a sacrament , too . Are you afraid of a little bread and wine that a priest has said a few words over ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia , don ’ t torment me . I tell you I can ’ t .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Scornfully .I never imagined you would be superstitious . You ’ re frightened . You feel just like people about sitting thirteen at table . Of course it ’ s all nonsense , but there may be something in it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t know what I feel . I only know that I , an unbeliever , can ’ t take part in a ceremony that was sacred to me when I believed .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Bitterly .It ’ s very natural . It only means that you love yourself better than anyone else . Why should one expect you to have pity for your father , or gratitude ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , Sylvia , where did you learn to say such cruel things ? I can ’ t , I tell you , I can ’ t . If father were in his normal mind , neither he nor mother would wish me to do such a thing .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But your mother does wish it . Oh , John , don ’ t be stubborn . For God ’ s sake give yourself the opportunity . Your father ’ s dying , John ; you have no time to lose .... John , the Communion Service has only just begun . If you get on your bicycle you ’ ll be there in time . The other day the Vicar said if you presented yourself at the Communion table he would not hesitate to administer it .

div.stage: JOHN looks steadily in front of him for a moment , then makes up his mind ; he stands up suddenly and without a word goes out of the room .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: In a whisper .O God , forgive me , forgive me , forgive me !

div.stage: The Curtain is lowered for one minute to denote the lapse of half an hour . When it rises SYLVIA is standing at the window , looking out into the garden .
MRS. LITTLEWOOD enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Littlewood , do !

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I met Dr. Macfarlane just outside my house , and he told me the Colonel was dead . I came with him to see if I could be of any use .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you . Is Dr. Macfarlane here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Yes . He went upstairs . Where is John ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: He ’ ll be here directly .

div.stage: MRS. WHARTON comes in , followed by DR. MACFARLANE . MRS. LITTLEWOOD goes up to her and the two old ladies kiss one another . For a moment they stand clasped in one another ’ s arms .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: My dear old friend !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It was dear of you to come , Charlotte . I knew you ’ d feel for me .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Now sit down , my dear Mrs. Wharton , sit down and rest yourself .He puts her into a chair and places a cushion behind her .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Hasn ’ t John come in yet ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ m sure he won ’ t be long now . He should be here almost at once .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Sylvia , my dear child , won ’ t you go and get Mrs. Wharton a cup of tea ? I think it would do her good .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , my dear , don ’ t trouble .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But it ’ s no trouble . You know I love doing things for you .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Everybody ’ s so very kind in this world . It makes one feel humble .... George and I have been married for five and thirty years . He never said a cross word to me . He was always gentle and considerate . I daresay I was very troublesome now and then , but he was never impatient with me .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Is it true that John and Sylvia are not going to be married after all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ m afraid so .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Isn ’ t it strange how people in this world seem to go out of their way to make themselves unhappy !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ ve talked it over with Sylvia . Religion means so much to her . She wouldn ’ t have minded if John had come back blind and crippled , she ’ d have devoted her life to him without a murmur .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: People always think they could put up with the faults we haven ’ t got . Somehow or other it ’ s always those we have that stick in their throats .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , Doctor , don ’ t say sarcastic things . You don ’ t know how deeply Sylvia is suffering . But it ’ s a matter of conscience . And I do see that one can ’ t ask anyone to compromise with his soul .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I have an idea our souls are like our manners , all the better when we don ’ t think too much about them .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Sylvia ’ s giving up a great deal . I don ’ t know what ’ s to become of her if she doesn ’ t marry John . When her mother dies she ’ ll only have thirty pounds a year .

div.stage: SYLVIA comes back with a cup of tea on a small tray and puts it on a table by MRS. WHARTON ’ S side .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Here is the tea , Mrs. Wharton .

lg.l: Oh , thank you , my dear , so much . You do spoil me .... I can ’ t imagine why
John is so long . He ’ s generally so very punctual .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: In a low voice .John came in , Mrs. Wharton .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , then , you saw him ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Did you speak to him ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Why did he go out again ? Where has he gone ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: He ’ ll be back immediately .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Drink your tea , dear lady , drink your tea .

div.stage: SYLVIA takes her place again at the window and looks into the garden . She takes no notice of the people in the room .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I ’ m glad to have you two old friends with me now . The only thing that really seems to belong to me any more is the past , and you were both so much part of it .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: You came here immediately after your honeymoon . Is that really thirty-five years ago ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: My mother and I were the first people who called on you . I remember how stylish we thought you in your green velvet , Evelyn .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I remember it well . I had it dyed black its third year . I think the fashions were very much more ladylike in those days . A bustle did set off a woman ’ s figure , there ’ s no denying that .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: What waists you had and how tight you used to lace !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I often wonder if the young people ever enjoy themselves as much as we used to . Do you remember the picnics we used to have ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: And now it ’ s all as if it had never been , all our love and pain and joy and sorrow . We ’ re just two funny old women , and it really wouldn ’ t have mattered a row of pins if we ’ d never been born .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I wonder , I wonder .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You ’ ve had the privilege of giving two sons to a noble cause . Wasn ’ t it worth while to be born for that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Sometimes I ’ ve asked myself if this world in which we ’ re living now isn ’ t hell . Perhaps all the unhappiness my husband caused me and the death of those two boys of mine is a punishment for sins that I committed in some other life in some other part of the universe .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Charlotte , sometimes you say things that frighten me . I ’ m haunted by the fear that you may destroy yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: I ? No , why should I ? I don ’ t feel that life is important enough for me to give it a deliberate end . I don ’ t trouble to kill the fly that walks over my ceiling .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I ’ ve been curing or killing people for hard on fifty years , and it seems to me that I ’ ve seen innumerable generations enter upon the shifting scene , act their little part , and pass away . Alas , who can deny that in this world virtue is very often unrewarded and vice unpunished ? Happiness too rarely comes to the good , and the prizes of this life go too frequently to the undeserving . The rain falls on the just and on the unjust alike , but the unjust generally have a stout umbrella . It looks as though there were little justice in the world , and chance seems to rule man and all his circumstances .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: But we know that all that is mere idle seeming .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Seeming perhaps , but why idle ? Seeming is all we know . The other day when you were talking I held my tongue , because I thought you ’ d say I was a silly old fool if I put my word in , but I ’ ve puzzled over suffering and pain too . You see , in my trade we see so much of them . It made me unhappy , and for long I doubted the goodness of God , as you doubt it , dear friend .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: With a smile .I think you ’ re preaching at me , Doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Then it ’ s the first time in my life .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I want to tell you how I found peace . My explanation is as old as the hills , and I believe many perfectly virtuous persons have been frizzled alive for accepting it . Our good Vicar would say I was a heretic . I can ’ t help it . I can ’ t see any other way of reconciling the goodness of God with the existence of evil .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Well , what is it ?

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: I don ’ t believe that God is all-powerful and all-knowing . But I think He struggles against evil as we do . I don ’ t believe He means to chasten us by suffering or to purify us by pain . I believe pain and suffering are evil , and that He hates them , and would crush them if He could . And I believe that in this age-long struggle between God and evil we can help , all of us , even the meanest ; for in some way , I don ’ t know how , I believe that all our goodness adds to the strength of God , and perhaps — who can tell ?— will give Him such power that at last He will be able utterly to destroy evil — utterly , with its pain and suffering .With a smile .When we ’ re good , we ’ re buying silver bullets for the King of Heaven , and when we ’ re bad , well , we ’ re trading with the enemy .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Without looking round .John has just ridden back on his bicycle .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Come , Mrs. Littlewood , they don ’ t want us here just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Getting up .No , I ’ m sure you will prefer to be alone with John .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It was very good of you to come . Good-bye , my dear , and God bless you .

sp.speaker: MRS. LITTLEWOOD
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: They kiss one another and MRS. LITTLEWOOD goes out .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Shaking hands with MRS. WHARTON .I may look in later in the day to see how you are .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Oh , my dear doctor , I ’ m not in the least ill , you know .

sp.speaker: DR. MACFARLANE
sp.p: Still , don ’ t try to do too much . You ’ re not quite a young woman , you know . Good-bye , Sylvia .

div.stage: SYLVIA does not answer . DR. MACFARLANE goes out . SYLVIA advances into the room and then turns and looks again at the door through which JOHN must come . She does all she can to control her great nervousness .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: Sylvia , is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No . Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You seem so strange .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Paying no attention to the remark .John is just coming .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You know , my dear , it seems to me that in this life most difficulties can be arranged if both parties are willing to give way a little .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Sometimes it ’ s impossible to give way , and then the only hope is — a miracle .

div.stage: She says the last word with a little smile to conceal the fact that she attaches the greatest importance to it . JOHN comes in . He is pale and looks extremely tired . He stops for a moment in surprise on seeing his mother . He goes over and kisses her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , mother , I thought you were upstairs . I ’ m afraid I ’ m very late .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: It doesn ’ t matter , my dear . How dreadfully white you look .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I went for a walk this morning . I ’ ve had nothing to eat . I ’ m rather tired .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: My dear , you frighten me , your face is all drawn and pinched .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , mother , don ’ t worry about me . I shall be all right after breakfast . After all , it ’ s quite enough to have one invalid on your hands .

div.stage: MRS. WHARTON looks at him in surprise . SYLVIA gives a nervous start , but immediately controls herself .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Have you been — where you said you were going ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: SYLVIA opens her mouth to speak , but stops ; she gives JOHN a long , searching look ; she realises that what she had hoped for has not taken place , and with a little gasp of misery turns away her head and sinks , dejected and exhausted , into a chair . JOHN has held her look with his and now turns to his mother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Is father asleep ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: With a little shiver .John !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I thought you knew . My dearest , your father ’ s dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I asked Sylvia to break it to you . I thought ....

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: In a dull voice .I didn ’ t tell him when you asked me to , Mrs. Wharton .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ t understand . It seems impossible . He was well enough last night . When did he die ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: At about seven this morning .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But , mother dear , why didn ’ t you call me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I didn ’ t expect it . We ’ d been talking and he said he was tired and he thought he could sleep a little . He dozed off quietly , and in a little while I saw he was dead .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , my poor mother , how will you bear your grief ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: You know , it ’ s so strange , I ’ m not in the least unhappy . I don ’ t feel that he ’ s left me . I feel him just as near to me as before . I don ’ t know how to explain it to you . I think he ’ s never been so much alive as now . Oh , John , I know that the soul is immortal .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Darling , I ’ m so glad you ’ re not unhappy . Your dear eyes are positively radiant .

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: If you only knew what I seem to see with them !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Won ’ t you take me up and let me see him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WHARTON
sp.p: I think the women are not done yet , John . I ’ ll go up and see . I ’ ll call you as soon as everything is ready .

lg.l: I ’ m sorry I ’ ve caused you so much pain since I came back , mother . I wish
I could have avoided it .

lg.stage: She puts her arms round his neck , and he kisses her .
lg.l: My dear son !

div.stage: She goes out . JOHN goes towards the window and looks out into the garden . For a moment SYLVIA does not dare to speak to him . At last she makes an effort .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Desperately .John , whatever you have to say to me , say it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With frigid politeness .I don ’ t think I have anything in particular to say to you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I suppose you think I ’ m just a wicked liar .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ask you no questions . I make you no reproaches . What is the matter ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Oh , John , after all we ’ ve been to one another it ’ s brutal to talk to me like that . If you think I did wrong , say so .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You ’ re cruel and hard .She goes up to him .John , you must listen to me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Your mother asked me to tell you of your father ’ s death . I concealed it from you . I told you a whole tissue of lies . I traded deliberately on your tenderness for your father . I was horrified at myself . It was my only chance of getting you to take the Communion .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If you ’ d had any affection for me , you couldn ’ t have done such an abominable thing . If you ’ d had any respect for me you couldn ’ t have done it .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Let me speak , John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Be quiet ! You ’ ve insisted on talking about it , and now , by God , you ’ re going to listen to me . Do you know what I felt ? Shame . When I took the bread and the wine , I thought they ’ d choke me . Because once I believed so devoutly it seemed to me that I was doing an awful thing . Deliberately , with full knowledge of what I was doing , I told a dirty lie . And I feel dirty to the depths of my soul .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I thought perhaps it wouldn ’ t be a lie . I had to do it , John . It was my only chance .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why did you do it ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Don ’ t look at me so sternly . I can ’ t bear it . You frighten me . I can ’ t collect my thoughts .

lg.l: Why did you do it ? Shall I tell you ? Because at the back of all your
Christian humility there ’ s the desire to dominate . It isn ’ t so much that
I didn ’ t believe as that I didn ’ t believe what you wanted me to believe .
You wanted to grind my face in the dust .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Passionately .John , if you only knew ! I only thought of you . I only thought of you all the time .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Don ’ t be such a hypocrite .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Brokenly .I expected a miracle .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: At this time of day ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: For God ’ s sake have mercy on me ! It was your mother who put the idea in my head . Your father received the Communion last night .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You have no charity for human weakness . You were all so terrified that he shouldn ’ t make an edifying end . As if it mattered if the poor dear ’ s nerve failed him at the last .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Eagerly .But it didn ’ t . That ’ s just it . You noticed your mother ’ s face yourself . Notwithstanding all her grief she ’ s happy . Do you know why ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: As though suddenly inspired .Because when he ’ d received the Blessed Sacrament the fear of death left him . He was once more a brave and gallant gentleman . He had no dread any longer of the perilous journey before him . He was happy to die .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: More gently .Is that true ? Dear father , I ’ m very glad .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: It was a miracle . It was a miracle .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I still don ’ t follow .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I thought that when you knelt at the chancel steps , and received the Communion as you used to receive it when you were a boy , all the feelings of your boyhood would rush back on you . I had to make you take it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In my frame of mind ? Surely I had no right to .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I know . That ’ s what makes my sin the greater . Perhaps I was mad . To God all things are possible . I felt certain you ’ d believe .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Very gravely .Perhaps you have worked a miracle , but not the one you expected .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: When you said you wouldn ’ t marry me I was — I was knocked endways — I felt like a man who ’ s been shipwrecked . All my plans for the future had been bound up with you . I couldn ’ t imagine it without you . I felt utterly forlorn .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: But don ’ t you know what it cost me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: At first I couldn ’ t think you meant it . When you said you didn ’ t love me , I couldn ’ t believe it . It seemed too preposterous . I was awfully miserable , Sylvia .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: John , I didn ’ t want you to be unhappy .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: And then , when I received the Communion something quite strange took place in me . I can ’ t tell you what I felt . I felt as though mother had heard me saying something obscene . I forced myself to go through with it , because I really did think it might give poor father some peace of mind . But it was you who made me do it . The thought of you filled me with horror .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: With dismay .John !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You ’ ve cured me , Sylvia . I ought to be grateful to you for that . My love for you has fallen from me as a cloak might fall from one ’ s shoulders . I see the truth now . You were quite right . In these long years we ’ ve become different people and we have nothing to say to one another any more .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Passionately .But I love you , John ! How can you be so blind ? Don ’ t you see that I only did it because I loved you ? Oh , John , you can ’ t leave me now ! I ’ ve waited for you all these years . I ’ ve longed for you to come back . Forgive me if I did wrong . I can ’ t lose you now . I love you , John , you won ’ t leave me ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: After a moment ’ s pause .Of course I won ’ t leave you . I thought you didn ’ t want to marry me .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Hardly knowing what she is saying .I ’ m not young any more . I ’ ve lost my freshness . I ’ ve got nobody but you now . Oh , John , don ’ t forsake me ! I couldn ’ t bear it .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: As though he were talking to a child .My dear , don ’ t distress yourself . I ’ m not thinking of forsaking you . We ’ ll be married as soon as ever we can .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Yes , we ’ ll be married , won ’ t we ? I love you so much , John , I ’ ll make you love me . I couldn ’ t lose you now . I ’ ve waited too long .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Come , darling , you mustn ’ t be unhappy . It ’ s all settled now . Dry your eyes . You don ’ t want to look a fright , do you ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Clinging to him .I ’ m so miserable .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nonsense , give me a nice kiss , and we ’ ll forget all about our troubles . I ’ ll try to make you a good husband , Sylvia . I ’ ll do all I can to make you happy . Give me a kiss .

div.stage: When he seeks to raise her face in order to kiss her , she tears herself violently from him .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , don ’ t ! Don ’ t touch me ! God give me strength ! I ’ m so pitifully weak .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sylvia !

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Don ’ t come near me ! For God ’ s sake !She puts her hands before her face , trying to control and to collect herself , and there is a moment ’ s pause .It never occurred to me that you didn ’ t care for me any more , and when you told me , for a moment I lost my head . Forgive me for that , dear , and forget it . I ’ m not going to marry you .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now , Sylvia , don ’ t be idiotic . It would be so unseemly if I had to drag you to the altar by the hair of your head .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You ’ re very kind , John . I suppose it wouldn ’ t be very good form to back out of it now . I ’ m poor , and I ’ ve wasted my best years waiting for you . You needn ’ t worry about what is going to happen to me . I can earn my living as well as other women .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , Sylvia , you ’ re torturing yourself and me . Can ’ t you forget what I said in a moment of exasperation ? You must know how deep my affection is for you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I don ’ t want to forget . It is the will of God . I lied . I did an abominable and evil thing . I don ’ t think you can imagine how terrible my sin has been . I risked my soul to save you , John , and God has inflicted on me a punishment infinitely less than I deserved . He has taken out of your heart the love you bore me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: But you love me , Sylvia .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Better than anyone in the world . I ’ ve loved you ever since I was a child of ten . That ’ s only the weakness of my flesh . My soul exults in the great mercy that God has shown me .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , my dear , you ’ re going to be so unhappy .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: No , don ’ t be sorry for me . You ’ ve given me a great opportunity .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: I ’ ve been mortified because I was able to do so little in the war . I knew it was my duty to stay here and look after mother . But I wanted to go out to France and do my bit like all my friends .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That was very natural .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Now at last I have the chance to do something . No sacrifice is worthless in the eyes of God . A broken and a contrite heart , O God , thou wilt not despise . I sacrifice now all that was precious to me in the world , my love and my hope of happiness in this life , and I sacrifice it with a cheerful heart , and I pray that God may accept it . So shall I do my part to atone for the sins which have brought on this horrible war .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It would have been better if I ’ d never come back . I ’ ve caused misery and suffering to all of you .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: John , you took away the ring you gave me when we became engaged . You threw it in the fire .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I ’ m afraid that was very silly of me . I did it in a moment of bitterness .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: You went into Canterbury to buy a wedding ring . What have you done with it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I have it here . Why ?

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Can I have it ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Of course .

div.stage: He takes it out of his waistcoat pocket , and , wondering , gives it to her .

sp.speaker: SYLVIA
sp.p: Slipping the ring on her finger .I will put the love of man out of my life . I will turn from what is poor and transitory to what is everlasting . I will be the bride of One whose love is never denied to them that seek it . The love of God is steadfast and enduring . I can put all my trust in that and I shall never find it wanting .... Good-bye , John , God bless you now and always .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good-bye , dear child .

div.stage: She goes out quickly . In a minute KATE comes in . She is carrying a square wooden box in which are papers , firewood , a hearth-brush , and a large soiled glove .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Please , sir , Mrs. Wharton says , will you go upstairs now ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: He goes out . KATE goes to the fire-place , kneels down , puts on the glove , and begins to rake out the ashes . The COOK enters . She is a stout homely body of forty-five .

sp.speaker: COOK
sp.p: The butcher ’ s come , Kate . I don ’ t exactly like to go up to Mrs. Wharton just now . I ’ ve got the cold beef for lunch , but they ’ ll be wanting something for dinner .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Oh , well , they always like best end . You can ’ t go far wrong if you have that .

sp.speaker: COOK
sp.p: I ’ ve got a fine lot of pease .

sp.speaker: KATE
sp.p: Well , they ’ ll do nicely .

sp.speaker: COOK
sp.p: I was thinking I ’ d make a fruit tart . I think p ’ raps I ’ d better order two and a half pounds of best end .

div.stage: She goes out . KATE continues to lay the fire .
